ExplntnTxt: Grantee submits annual financial reports. Each report includes spending of GtCNN funds by line item, a budget variance report, revenues received from other sources, and total program expenditures. At the end of the grant period (3-4 years) the grantee submits a final report. Reports are reviewed by GtCNN staff and inquiries are made at the time for any questioned items.
- A committee is assigned to consider student applicants and assign scholarships on a non-discriminatory basis.
Policy guides, accounting software, and annual audit.

THE NEWSEUM INSTITUTE OFFERS SEVERAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS DURING THE YEAR. MONITORING OF THESE FUNDS IS NOT REQUIRED AS THE GRANTS ARE ONLY MADE TO THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE INSTITUTE'S CLASSES.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED FOR APPROPRIATE USE BY MONITORING REGISTRATION AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF COURSES AND PROGRAMS TOWARDS EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
ALL GRANTS ARE PAID TO A RELATED ORGANIZATION. GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED ACCORDING TO THE INTERNAL STANDARDS OF THE RELATED ORGANIZATION.

DISBURSEMENTS TO STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THOSE RECEIVING AID ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID OR ASSISTANCE FROM A GOVERNMENTAL AGENCY IS DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS USING FEDERALLY APPROVED FINANCIAL NEED ANALYSIS CRITERIA.

TABOR COLLEGE EVALUATES EACH STUDENT FOR FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID USING THE INFORMATION ON THE FAFSA FORM AS WELL AS OTHER APPLICATION MATERIALS COMPLETED FOR THEIR INSTITUTIONAL AID OFFERINGS. STUDENTS MUST MEET ALL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION GUIDELINES TO RECEIVE FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID, INCLUDING LOANS. SUCH GUIDELINES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS, ATTENDANCE, NUMBER OF HOURS, AND A CLEAN FINANCIAL AID HISTORY. STUDENTS MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR MERIT-BASED AID AND SOME MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. IN ADDITION TO BOTH NEED- AND MERIT-BASED QUALIFICATIONS, STUDENTS MUST MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN AID ELEMENTS. ALL DETERMINATIONS ARE MADE BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IN CONJUNCTION WITH ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS, ATHLETIC DEPARTMENTS, ADMISSIONS STAFF, AND DEVELOPMENT/ADVANCEMENT STAFF.

THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE PROGRAM BY REVIEWING EACH GRANTOR'S REQUIRED SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA AND THEN HAVING THE STUDENT FILL OUT A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION IN ORDER TO SEE IF THE STUDENT MEETS THE CRITERIA. THE COLLEGE HAS A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHO REVIEWS THE APPLICATIONS AND CRITERIA AND APPROVES SCHOLARSHIPS FOR EACH STUDENT.

The Academy provides scholarships to individuals to attend the Academy. Scholarship receipients are selected based on a written application which is reviewed by the Academy's faculty and staff. Scholarships are awarded based on a combination of student financial need, academic merit, and other factors and are applied directly to the student's account as a reduction in tuition and fees. The Academy monitors each recipient student to ensure that he/she remains an active, enrolled student and satisfies the academic and other criteria for maintaining the scholarship.
Missions giving is approved by Board of Directors after review of recipient organization.
Scholarships are awarded by Seminary after review of application materials.
The college has policies and procedures to determine eligibility for student financial assistance. They also comply with the Federal requirements for awarding student aid.

FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS AT THE UNIVERSITY ARE FUNDED THROUGH A VARIETY OF SOURCES. IT IS INTENDED THAT THE VARIOUS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS BE USED TO RECOGNIZE ACADEMIC, ATHLETIC, SERVANT LEADERSHIP, AND SPECIAL ACHIEVEMENT MEET FINANCIAL NEEDS OR PROVIDE SELF-HELP OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STUDENT WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS AND PARENT/STUDENT LOANS. WHILE IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO GUARANTEE THAT FUNDING WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR EVERY NEEDY APPLICANT, THE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS AT THE UNIVERSITY ARE DESIGNED TO HELP COVER THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE DIRECT COST OF ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY AND THE STUDENTS OWN RESOURCES. EACH APPLICATION IS REVIEWED BASED UPON AN INDIVIDUAL ASSESSMENT IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE TYPE OF RESOURCES THAT WILL BEST SERVE THE STUDENT.

Scholarships are awarded to students based upon criteria such as need, area of study, grade point average, among others, as established by scholarship documents and donor restrictions. Scholarships are applied to the students' accounts to help cover the costs of tuition, room, and board.

EARTH University Foundation was formed to support the educational mission of the Escuela de Agricultura de La Region Tropical Humeda through generous gifts from the global community and other programs and initiatives. The Foundation is a registered 501(c)(3) public charity headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia. EARTH University is an international institution created out of a deep conviction that the environmental and social challenges confronting the planet can be resolved through education that promotes science, technology and entrepreneurship while focusing on essential human values, leadership and a commitment to social and environmental service. The University provides support to the Earth University Foundation to cover administrative expenses. The Foundation intends that most of the money it raises be directed to the University to support its educational mission. The University requires periodic reports from the Foundation on the expenses it incurs and the manner in which it is using monies provided by the University. Since the Foundation's primary exempt purpose is to support the University's mission, there is no concern that monies sent to the Foundation will be used other than for a purpose that furthers the University's mission.
THE GRANTS (SCHOLARSHIPS) MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE A REDUCTION OF THE TUITION AND FEES PAID BY THE STUDENT TO THE SCHOOL. GRANT FUNDS ARE NOT SENT TO OUTSIDE ENTITIES.

The federal aid office of the University requires students to complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for Federal, State, and Institutional grants, scholarships, and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the Institution does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based upon certain academic credentials or performance in a University sponsored activity. These credentials are clearly stated in the University catalog and the University website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitored by the University.

The Board issued a RFP for grant proposals, met and considered four applications, whether they were in line with entrepreneurship and job creation in the local community, and then voted to award the funds to the most qualified agencies. The Grantee is to submit a report at the end of the grant period describing the project and provide a report showing how the funds were spent. Funds are to be expended as outlined in the grant proposal.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF NEED AND MERIT. FUNDS ARE APPLIED TO INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNTS, AND RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S DOCUMENT RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The Director of Development communicates eligible expenses to Accounting , Business Office and others. The expenses are received and reviewed by the Business Office (COO) as well as reviewed by Controller and Vice President of Finance to ensure compliance with grant requirements, coding, and if costs are allowed. A reconciliation of grant expenditures to accounting records is done monthly and a federal financial report of cash draw downs is completed quarterly. Monitoring of budgeted amounts compared to actual costs is done monthly so that allowable funds are identified and fully utilized within the funding period.
THE FOUNDATION GRANTS AMOUNTS DIRECTLY TO THE VIRGINIA COMMONWEALTH UNIVERSITY (UNIVERSITY). ALL FUNDS ARE USED DIRECTLY IN COMPLETING THE EDUCATIONAL PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY.

THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THE RESULT OF TITLE IV AID, THEN THESE FUNDS ARE AUTOMATICALLY DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK WITHIN FOURTEEN DAYS. IF THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE THE RESULT OF SOMETHING OTHER THAN TITLE IV AID, THE STUDENT MUST REQUEST A REFUND AND THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.
SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATIONS AND STUDENT TRANSCRIPTS ARE REVIEWED AND KEPT ON FILE TO ENSURE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS ARE MET FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED.
FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF NEED AND/OR MERIT AS DETERMINED BY SEMINARY ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID PERSONNEL

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are provided to students based on specific criteria established by student financial services in regards to eligibility, student selection and requirements of the scholarship. Each scholarship recipient will be monitored by the University to confirm that they have satisfied all scholarship requirements. The actual scholarships are credited to the students tuition bills. No scholarships are awarded directly to the student.

HODGES UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN VARIOUS LOCAL SPONSORSHIPS TO ORGANIZATIONS ANNUALLY BASED ON OUR ABILITY AND CURRENT ECONOMIC SITUATION. BECAUSE THE SPONSORSHIPS ARE FOR GENERAL OPERATING SUPPORT, NO MONITORING IS REQUIRED. HODGES UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN BOTH STATE AND FEDERAL STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. VIRTUALLY ALL FUNDS RECEIVED ARE IMMEDIATELY CREDITED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS FOR PAYMENT OF TUITION, FEES AND BOOKS. EXCESS FUNDS ARE DELIVERED TO STUDENTS ACCORDING TO PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS.

The college does not provide grants or assistance to organizations other than assistance to individuals in the form of studentscholarships. Should the College consider future grant awards to organiztations, monitoring will be done in accordance with OMB Circular A-133's, "Subrecipient Monitoring' procedures.

Grants and scholarships are awarded to students based on specific criteria detailed in the various grant/scholarship agreements. Members of the financial aid office and various scholarship/award committees review records for all potential recipients to ensure that the scholarship/award is being awarded properly.

Disbursements to students receiving financial aid are made in accordance with institutional procedures to ensure that those receiving the aid are qualifying recipients. These recipients are judged worthy by assessing their academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.

GRANT FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE APPLICABLE REGULATIONS. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED ACCORDING TO ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA INCLUDING SCHOLASTIC ABILITY, CHRISTIAN INVOLVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND/OR TALENT. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ACCOUNTED FOR IN SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS WHICH ARE RECONCILED INTERNALLY. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AUDITED ANNUALLY IN COMPLIANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

INITIAL MERIT AID FOR NEW FIRST YEAR AND TRANSFER FULL TIME DAY STUDENTS IS DETERMINED BY VARIABLES SUCH AS ACT TEST SCORES, HIGH SCHOOL GPA, TOP % OF HIGH SCHOOL CLASS, AND TRANSFER GPA. THIS INFORMATION IS DATA ENTERED INTO THE SOFTWARE AND THEN A FACTOR IS DETERMINED. THAT FACTOR DETERMINES THE MERIT AID THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. RULES IN THE SOFTWARE ALERT MANUAL AWARD ENTRY ERROR. RENEWAL OF MERIT AID IS DETERMINED AT THE TIME OF AWARDING THE AID FOR THE NEXT YEAR BY REVIEWING GRAND VIEW GPA AND SEMESTERS OF RECEIVED AID. AS A FOLLOW-UP FOR THOSE AWARDED PRIOR TO THE SPRING GRADES, A REPORT IS REVIEWED TO DETERMINE IF THE GPA CRITERIA WAS MET AT THE END OF THE TERM. GRAND VIEW IS A MEMBER OF THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF INTERCOLLEGIATE ATHLETICS AND OFFERS ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS IN BASEBALL, BASKETBALL, BOWLING, CROSS COUNTRY, FOOTBALL, GOLF, SOCCER, TRACK AND FIELD, WRESTLING, VOLLEYBALL AND TENNIS FOR MEN, AND BASKETBALL, BOWLING, COMPETITIVE DANCE, CROSS COUNTRY, GOLF, SOCCER, SOFTBALL, TRACK AND FIELD, VOLLEYBALL AND TENNIS FOR WOMEN. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON ABILITY AS EVALUATED BY THE COACHES. TO QUALIFY, STUDENTS MUST VISIT CAMPUS, INTERVIEW WITH AND BE RECOMMENDED BY THE COACH, APPLY AND BE ACCEPTED TO THE UNIVERSITY. COACHES ARE GIVEN A BUDGET FOR THE YEAR TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN PLAYERS. APPEALS FOR ADDITIONAL DOLLARS ARE MONITORED BY THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT. BUDGETS ARE MONITORED BY ATHLETIC ADMINISTRATIVE COORDINATOR, ATHLETIC DIRECTOR, FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR, AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS ARE REVIEWED BY THE ATHLETIC SUCCESS COORDINATOR AND THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR. COMMUNICATION OF STUDENT AWARDS IS DONE VIA EMAIL BETWEEN THE ATHLETIC ADMINISTRATIVE COORDINATOR AND FINANCIAL AID. ART, MUSIC & THEATER AWARDS ARE AWARDED TO FULL TIME DAY STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE TALENT. TO QUALIFY, STUDENTS MUST VISIT CAMPUS, MEET WITH THE CHAIR OF THE DEPARTMENT, APPLY AND BE ACCEPTED TO GRAND VIEW. RENEWAL IS BASED ON GPA OR GOOD STANDING. EACH DEPARTMENT HAS A BUDGET TO USE TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN STUDENTS. COMMUNICATIONS FOR INITIAL AWARDS ARE GIVEN TO THE ADMISSIONS DIRECTOR AND FORWARDED TO THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR. ROSTERS OF THOSE TO RENEW ARE SENT TO THE CHAIR TO EVALUATE BASED ON GPA, ACADEMIC STANDING AND PARTICIPATION. BUDGETS ARE MONITORED BY FINANCIAL AID. AN ALERT WILL BE GIVEN IF AN AWARD IS ENTERED OVER THE BUDGETED AMOUNT. ANNUAL AND ENDOWED AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON DONOR QUALIFICATIONS. ADVANCEMENT, BUSINESS OFFICE, AND FINANCIAL AID SIGN OFF AND RECEIVE COPIES OF NEW FUNDS CREATED. THE ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID WORKS WITH THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND ADVANCEMENT TO DETERMINE WHICH FUNDS AND THE DOLLAR AMOUNT TO BE AWARDED IN A GIVEN YEAR IN JANUARY. NOTIFICATIONS GO TO DEPARTMENTS OF FACULTY PICKS. FINANCIAL AID PICKS ARE DETERMINED BY RUNNING A REPORT TO GET STUDENTS WHO MEET DONOR REQUIREMENTS. MOST OF THESE AWARDS REQUIRE A SCHOLARSHIP ACCEPTANCE AND THANK YOU TO THE DONOR. DISBURSEMENT RULES WILL NOT ALLOW THE FUND TO BE DISBURSED UNTIL THIS DOCUMENTATION IS RECEIVED. PACKAGING PROCEDURES ARE DEVELOPED EACH YEAR AND UTILIZED TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S TOTAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. IN THIS WAY, AID IS GIVEN IN A FAIR AND EQUITABLE MANNER.

CARROLL COLLEGE AND FEDERAL NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE FEDERAL FAFSA AND NEEDS ANALYSIS. NEW STUDENT MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GPA AND TEST SCORES OR TRANSFER GPA FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS. STATE GRANT REPORTING IS COMPLETED EACH YEAR AFTER THE ACADEMIC YEAR IS COMPLETED. FEDERAL FISAP REPORTING IS COMPLETED PRIOR TO OCTOBER OF EACH YEAR FOLLOWING THE COMPLETION OF THE ACADEMIC YEAR.
SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CREDITED TO THEIR ACCOUNT WITH THE UNIVERSITY TO OFFSET TUITION AND OTHER SIMILIAR COSTS. NO CASH IS AWARDED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE PURSUING A DEGREE OFFERED BY ALLEN COLLEGE AND MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF PARTICULAR SCHOLARSHIPS. A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM ALLEN COLLEGE AND THE MEMORIAL FOUNDATION OF ALLEN HOSPITAL REVIEW APPLICATIONS AND SELECT INDIVIDUALS WHO QUALIFY.
STUDENT FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY IN ORDER TO ENSURE GRANT FUNDS ARE AWARDED APPROPRIATELY BASED ON THE INDIVIDUAL AWARD CRITERIA.

ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AS EITHER NEED-BASED OR MERIT-BASED AWARDS. TO AWARD OR ADMINISTER NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID FOLLOWS FEDERAL GUIDELINES STARTING WITH THE EVALUATION OF EACH STUDENT FOR "NEED" BASED ON FAFSA & NEED-ACCESS REPORTS. MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY COMMITTEES ESTABLISHED BY THE DEAN OF THE SCHOOL. ONCE AWARDEES ARE CHOSEN, THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED THROUGH THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID. ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH ACADEMIC YEAR (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND CURRENT ENROLLMENT) IS VERIFIED BY THE DIRECTOR PRIOR TO INITIAL DISBURSEMENT OF ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND ELIGIBILITY IS VERIFIED AGAIN FOR THE JANUARY TERM BEFORE SECOND TERM DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE.
HALLMARK MAKES GRANTS TO WORTHY ORGANIZATIONS THAT HAVE THE SAME BELIEFS AS THE UNIVERSITY.

Gardner-Webb University practices a yearly review (at the end of the Spring Semester) to monitor all students awarded an Institutional Scholarship based on the following criteria: 1) enrollment status 2) housing status 3) GPA 4) maintaining Satisfactory Academic Progress in accordance with the University's policy.

BAKER UNIVERSITY MONITORS ALL GRANTS WITH SPECIFIC INQUIRIES AND REVIEWS ON A QUARTERLY BASIS. ALL GRANTS ARE PLACED UNDER THE RESPONSIBILITY OF ONE INDIVIDUAL WITHIN THE ORGANIZATION. THE BUSINESS OFFICE WILL THEN ASSIST IN PREPARING DOCUMENTS WHICH ARE TYPICALLY REQUIRED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.
ANNUAL A-133 AUDIT

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are granted to deserving students based on the terms of the grant establishing the particular scholarship fund. For example, some scholarships are available only to students in the Missions Department, or Music majors, etc., while some scholarships funds can be given to any student who can show a need.Scholarships and grants are placed on student receivable accounts except in a few exceptional cases. If there is a credit balance left on the student account no amounts are refunded until any unused scholarships or grants are reversed.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.
STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS USING FEDERAL FAFSA APPLICATIONS. SPECIFIC CRITERIA ARE APPLIED TO CONFIRM ELIGIBILITY AND TO ASSURE FAIRNESS TO ALL APPLICANTS.

THE ORGANIZATION OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS TO GRADUATING STUDENTS WHO ARE CONTINUING THEIR EDUCATION. THE GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO THE RECIPIENTS AND THEY ARE TO USE THE FUNDS WITHIN FIVE YEARS FOR THEIR EDUCTION. SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE ONLY RELEASED WHEN THE RECIPIENT HAS PROVIDED A REASON AND QUANTITATED THE ACTUAL EXPENSES. THOSE EXPENSES MUST BE APPROVED BEFORE PAYMENT IS MADE.

FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ARE PROCESSED AND MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ENDOWMENT SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS AND ENTITLEMENT AWARDS ARE COORDINATED AND MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL FINANCIAL AID OFFERS ARE REVIEWED BY THE ADMINISTRATIVELY APPOINTED STUDENT FINANCE COMMITTEE. WORK STUDY POSITIONS ARE OFFERED AND REGULATED BY THE PERSONNEL OFFICER IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE FACULTY MEMBER OR ADMINISTRATIVE SUPERVISOR.
ONCE TROCAIRE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS, DISCOUNTS, AND/OR STUDENT AID, AND THE STUDENT ACCEPTS THOSE FUNDS, THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY CREDITS THE STUDENTS TUITION BILL.
Students receiving scholarships are evaluated by the College's assessment of academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: All grants made by the School are to its students to cover costs of tuition and related expenses. All students who apply for scholarship or financial aid must complete the Federal Student Aid Application (FAFSA) to determine eligibility.

GRANT FUNDS ARE ONLY AWARDED TO THOSE STUDENTS WHO MEET THE REQUIREMENTS FOR A PARTICULAR GRANT OR GRANTS. ALSO, THEY MUST MEET OUR SATISFACTORY PROGRESS POLICY TO CONTINUE RECEIVING THESE FUNDS, WHETHER IT IS FEDERAL GOVERNMENT OR FAULKNER UNIVERSITY FUNDS.
All educational and boarding expenses are paid directly to Universities & landlords. Deminimis personal expenses are not tracked.
THE FOUNDATION REQUIRES THAT THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAIN AND TRACK THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY PROJECT.

SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE NOT FROM GRANTS, BUT ARE TRACKED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF BIG BEND COMMUNITY COLLEGE, BILLED TO THE FOUNDATION FROM BIG BEND COMMUNITY COLLEGE AND THEN PAID TO BIG BEND COMMUNITY COLLEGE. THE FUNDS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS COME FROM DONORS AND FUNDRAISERS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: MERCY COLLEGE OF OHIO FOLLOWS THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES OF THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FOR TITLE IV GRANTS AND THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES OF THE OHIO BOARD OF REGENTS FOR ALL STATE GRANTS.

STUDENTS AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS MUST BE ENROLLED, AND FOR CONTINUED FUNDING, MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE THE SEMESTER PROJECT; SOME SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRES MANUSCRIPT SUBMISSION, REVIEW AND SELECTION BY FACULTY.

MONIES GIVEN TO THESE ORGANIZATIONS ARE FOR THE SUPPORT OF ANOTHER ORGANIZATION THAT THE COLLEGE ADMINISTRATION BELIEVES IS WORTHY OF THEIR SUPPORT. THE USE OF THE FUNDS IS MONITORED IN THAT THE COLLEGE KNOWS THAT THE SPECIFIC INDIVIDUALS WHO WORK FOR THOSE ORGANIZATIONS ARE ON THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS MINISTERING TO STUDENTS. REGARDING SCHOLARSHIPS, THESE ARE VERY SELDOM PAID IN CASH. THE SCHOLARSHIPS (WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A FEW SMALL HONORS DAY AWARDS) ARE PLACED DIRECTLY ON THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS AND THE SCHOLARSHIPS NEVER EXCEED THE TOTAL COSTS CHARGED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants provided for Student Financial Aid are awarded by the Financial Aid Office based on appropriate guidelines. All awards are posted directly to the students' account and reviewed by the College's Business Office.

CIIS OFFERS INSTITUIONAL FUNDED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED BY EACH STUDENTS EFC (EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION) WHICH IS CALCULATED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION BASED ON THE STUDENTS FASFA. ALL STUDENTS MUST BE FULL-TIME AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING TO RECEIVE THE OPPORTUNITY SCHOLARSHIP. OPPORTUNITY SCHOLARSHIP IS CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AND IS AUTOMATICALLY APPLIED TO TUITION AND FEES ONLY.
THE COLLEGE OF FELLOWS REQUIRES TWO REPORTS EACH YEAR FROM THE RECIPIENTS. THOSE REPORTS ARE REVIEWED BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE.

AUGSBURG COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE UNIVERSITY ATTEMPTS TO MAKE ADEQUATE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS WITHIN THE LIMITS OF EACH STUDENT BUDGET AND THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, PROFESSIONAL PROMISE, LEADERSHIP POTENTIAL, FINANCIAL NEED AND/OR SPECIFIC GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY DONORS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED ON THE BASIS OF INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). ADDITIONALLY, THE UNIVERSITY MAKES AVAILABLE FEDERAL WORK STUDY FUNDS TO STUDENTS IN WHICH ELIGIBLE AWARD AMOUNTS ARE ALSO BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED INFORMATION PROVIDED WITHIN THE FAFSA. WORK STUDY EXPENDED AND AVAILABLE FUNDS ARE TRACKED AND REVIEWED THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO ASSISTED BY PROVIDING FUNDS FOR GENERAL OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO THE HEALTH EDUCATION AND RESIDENCY TRAINING NETWORK, A CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION ESTABLISHED TO PROMOTE AND SUPPORT COLLABORATION OF MEMBER MEDICAL AND EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS IN EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR MEDICAL STUDENTS,INTERNS AND RESIDENTS.
ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DETERIMINED BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE DONOR OR INSTITUTION.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: the $10,000 DONATION TO HAVE A HEART FUND IS A DONATION MADE EACH YEAR TO CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY AT MONTEREY BAY FOR THEIR ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDRAISER. THE USE OF FUNDS IS MANAGED BY THE FOUNDATION OF CSU MONTEREY BAY.
SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION: SCHEDULE I, PART IV SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION THE CONGRESSIONAL SCHOLARSHIP AND THE LEADERSHIP PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS ARE TRACKED THROUGH ANNUAL REGISTRATION.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ADMINISTERED WITHIN THE GUIDELINES OF THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. WILLIAM CAREY UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID AND BUSINESS DEPARTMENTS MONITOR THE PROGRAMS TO ASSURE THAT THEY FOLLOW FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE INDEPENDENT AUDITORS PERFORM AN AUDIT ON ALL FEDERAL PROGRAMS ANNUALLY.

ANY SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS TO STUDENTS ARE DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IN WHICH EACH STUDENT FILE IS REVIEWED IN ACCORDANCE WITH DESIGNATED ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE THEN MONITORED BY DISBURSING FUNDS FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT OFFICE.
THE COLLEGE MONITORS ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS BY ASSESSING STUDENT RECORDS, FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS FOR AWARDS.

FINANCIAL AID: HSC OFFERS A VARIETY OF ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. HSC ALSO OFFERS NEED-BASED GRANTS TO THOSE STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED BASED ON FAMILY INCOME INFORMATION PROVIDED IN THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE. SCHOLARSIHPS: THE OFFICE OF ADMISSION HAS PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROCESSING ALL SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATIONS. THE OFFICE OF ADMISSION USES THE DATA SUBMITTED ON THE APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION IN ORDER TO AWARD SCHOLARSHIPS. THE ADMISSIONS COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE APPLICATIONS, INCLUDING LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION, STUDENT ESSAY, AND EXTRA-CURRICULAR INVOLVEMENT. THE COMMITTEE RECOMMENDS THE LEVEL OF SCHOLARSHIP A STUDENT IS AWARDED. THIS INFORMATION IS THEN ADDED TO THE ADMISSION FILE AND THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNT IS FORWARDED TO THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNT IS INCLUDED AS PART OF THE TOTAL FINANCIAL AID AWARD. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID NOTIFIES ALL STUDENTS IN WRITING CONCERNING THEIR FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are applied directly to the student's account at the University and used on education.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A LISTING OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.

ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: USE OF GRANT FUNDING MUST COMPLY WITH THE INSTITUTION'S PURCHASING POLICY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. PRIMARY INVESTIGATORS ARE ULTIMATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE USE OF THOSE FUNDS UNDER THE REVIEW OF THE CONTRACT AND GRANTS ACCOUNTING MANAGER THAT MONITORS THEIR COMPLIANCE. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE IS SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL AUDIT (UNIFORM GUIDANCE) ENSURING AN OUTSIDE OPINION ON THE INSTITUTION'S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

THE COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH THE U.S. DEP. OF EDUCATION POLICY REGARDING TITLE IV FUNDS AND OTHER GRANT AWARDS. THE COLLEGE HAS DEDICATED INDIVIDUALS PERFORM THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE SCOPE OF THE GRANT. THESE INDIVIDUALS ARE CLASSIFIED AS FINANCIAL AID PROFESSIONALS AND GRANT ADMINISTRATORS WHO WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH FINANCE PROFESSIONALS TO ENSURE PROPER STEWARDSHIP OF FUNDS. THESE INDIVIDUALS FOLLOW THE STATUTORY AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN THE GRANT. FUNDS ARE DRAWN AFTER EXPENSES ARE INCURRED. PROGRESS REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: FUNDS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS FOR TUITION ASSISTANCE TO ATTEND THE 2015- 2016 ACADEMIC SCHOOL YEAR.
ALL GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH EACH GRANT. THEY ARE ALSO MONITORED BY MEMBERS OF SENIOR STAFF.

Most University of Saint Francis students receive financial aid. The Office of Financial Aid at the University of Saint Francis administers financial aid from federal, state, institutional, and private resources according to the Federal guidelines provided by the U.S. Department of Education. The University of Saint Francis bases financial aid awards on the information submitted by the student and family via the FASFA, as well as the student's academic records.

THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDED GRANTS TO THE ABOVE-MENTIONED PUBLIC CHARITIES TO ENABLE INDIVIDUALS WORKING AT THE GRANTEES TO ATTEND THE ORGANIZATION'S CLASSROOM EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AS STUDENTS. THE GRANT AWARD LETTERS PROHIBIT THE GRANTEE FROM USING THE GRANT FUNDS FOR LOBBYING AND POLITICAL PURPOSES, AND MAY REQUIRE THE GRANTEE TO FURNISH A REPORT TO THE ORGANIZATION DESCRIBING THE CHARITABLE AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES IN CONNECTION WITH THE ORGANIZATION'S EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FULFILLED BY THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

OTHER ASSISTANCE AS OTHER UNIVERSITY SUPPORT IS PROVIDED TO THE UNIVERSITY BY DISBURSING DONATED FUNDS TO VARIOUS EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES OF THE UNIVERSITY. THESE DISBURSEMENTS REQUIRE DOCUMENTATION STATING THE REASON FOR THE DISBURSEMENT AND ARE APPROVED BY A SUPERVISOR KNOWLEDGABLE ABOUT THE ACTIVITY REQUESTING THE FUNDING.
Students receiving Scholarships and Fellowships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards.

STUDENT AID IS PROVIDED ONLY TO ENROLLED STUDENTS WITH NEED AND WHO ALSO MEET ALL OF THE OTHER FEDERAL AID OR INSTITUTIONAL REQUIREMENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENT ELIGIBILITY AT THE BEGINNING OF EACH ACADEMIC YEAR AND TERM WITH FREQUENT PERIODIC UPDATES. RECIPIENTS ARE CHOSEN BY THE STUDENT AFFAIRS COMMITTEE BASED ON PUBLISHED CRITERIA. THE BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORS DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS.

The College awards scholarships from restricted funds to veterans who enroll in its degree or designation programs. These amounts are deducted directly from student accounts as they register for covered courses.

ExplntnTxt: Although IU Health Arnett does not monitor the use of grant funds once distributed, through due diligence the organization has reasonably confirmed that the entities to which the contributions are made are highly reputable in the community and use the funds for the purposes intended.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE INSTITUTION TRACKS THIS INFORMATION BY SOURCE IN ITS ENTERPRISE RESOURCE PLANNING SYSTEM.

Students receiving scholarships are judged worthy thereof through the institution's assessment based on academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards. Use of funds is monitored according to standards as published in the student handbook which include satisfactory academic progress standards.

Scholarship recipients are selected based on established merit and need-based criteria. The Financial Aid Director and Academic Department Heads work together to select institutional scholarship recipients. Qualifications for scholarships vary. All scholarships are monitored by the Financial Aid Department.

INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED BY THE BOARD, AUTHORIZED BY THE DEAN, AND AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED. THESE FUNDS ARE DEDUCTED FROM STUDENT TUITION. THE INSTITUTE MONITORS STUDENT ACCOUNTS TO DETERMINE ENROLLMENT AND ELIGIBILITY.

USE OF GRANT FUNDS: THE COLLEGE HAS IN PLACE ASSURANCES/SAFEGUARDS THAT INCLUDE GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING STANDARDS, AND ADDITIONAL FISCAL PROCEDURES FOR THE SUBMISSION AND APPROVAL OF INVOICES FOR THE PROPER USE OF GRANT FUNDS. FOR EXPENDITURES THAT PROVIDE SPECIFIC ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS (IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO PAY FOR TUITION, SUPPLIES AND FEES), THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE KEEPS COMPLETE AND ACCURATE INFORMATION ON EACH INDIVIDUAL RECIPIENT THAT INCLUDES DATA ON ELIGIBILITY, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND AMOUNT OF FUNDS AWARDED/DISBURSED. FOR EXPENDITURES IN SUPPORT OF PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES PROGRAM MANAGERS MUST REVIEW EXPENDITURE REQUESTS TO ENSURE THAT EACH IS AN APPROPRIATE EXPENDITURE FOR APPROVED ACTIVITIES IN THE APPROVED BUDGET FOR THE GRANT.
THE UNIVERSITY REVIEWS AND APPLIES CRITERIA BASED ON CIRCUMSTANCE, GRADE-POINT AVERAGE AND NEED. THE PROCESS IS APPLIED CONSISTENTLY TO ALL STUDENTS OF THE INSTITUTION.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF SCHOLASTIC ABILITY, PERSONAL PRESENTATION SKILLS AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN A MINIMUM GPA OF 2.5 TO QUALIFY FOR CONSIDERATION FOR ANY ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING.

FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED OF THE RECIPIENT'S FAMILY. FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND SUGGESTED FINANCIAL NEED OF THE RECIPIENT'S PARENT(S) OR GUARDIAN(S) IS PROVIDED TO THE SCHOOL BY AN INDEPENDENT THIRD PARTY.

The College follows state and federal guidelines in providing financial aid to students as well as internal criteria based upon academic progress, criteria established by particular scholarships, and/or financial need. The federal FAFSA form is used in this process as well.

Students submit the Federal FAFSA and this form is reviewed to award scholarships and other tuition discounts. Students also receive awards based on service (athletics) and well as academic or extracurricular achievements. The Director of Financial aid and the VP of enrollment maintain appropriate records to substantiate any financial assistance students receive. That information is subject to annual audit under OMB A-133 for any federal money the school receives. Awards are credited to students accounts. Accounts are reconciled throughout the year.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE OFFICE OF ADVANCEMENT WORKS WITH DONORS TO ESTABLISH GUIDELINES FOR THE USE AND DISBURSEMENT OF ANY DONATED FUNDS ACCORDING TO THE DONOR'S WISHES AND WITHIN PRACTICAL AND LEGAL PROCESSES. THE DONOR'S RESTRICTIONS ("WISHES") ARE PUT IN WRITING WITH COPIES MAINTAINED IN THE ADVANCEMENT OFFICE, THE CONTROLLER'S OFFICE, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, IF APPLICABLE. IF THE DONATION IS FOR GRANTS OR SCHOLARSHIPS TO BE DISTRIBTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS A SPREADSHEET OF GRANT TITLES AND RESTRICTIONS WHICH ARE UPDATED AS NEEDED AS WELL AS A PERMANENT ELECTRONIC FILE. THE GRANTS OR SCHOLARSHIPS ARE "MATCHED" WITH AN ELIGIBLE RECIPIENT BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE ADVANCEMENT OFFICE WILL RECEIVE A LIST OF THESE RECIPIENTS IN THE FALL AND AN UPDATED LIST IN THE EARLY SPRING. THE ADVANCEMENT OFFICE REVIEWS THE LIST AND PREPARES LUNCHEON INVITATIONS FOR MOST OF THE RECIPIENTS AND DONORS. THE FINAL STEP IN THE PROCESS IS A RANDOM AUDIT CONDUCTED ONCE A YEAR BY AN OUTSIDE AUDIT FIRM.

NEED-BASED GRANTS WERE AWARDED TO WARREN WILSON COLLEGE STUDENTS BASED ON FAFSA (FREE APPLICATION FOR STUDENT AID) RESULTS. FAFSA RESULTS ARE NOT REQUIRED TO BE CONSIDERED FOR MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS, BUT MANY OF THESE DOLLARS WERE USED TO MEET THE FEDERAL DEFINITION OF 'NEED'.

Grants to individuals: The University provides financial assistance to students that submit a written application and meet the University's criteria for financial assistance. Applications are reviewed by the Financial Aid Department and/or scholarship committees, depending upon the particular terms of each scholarship. Awards are applied against the student's tuition due to the University. The University monitors each student to assure that he/she remains enrolled in school and continues to satisfy the criteria for his/her specific scholarship. If the student withdraws from the University, then any remaining funds are returned to the scholarship pool to be awarded to another student.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE, FINANCIL AID DEPA RTMENT AND GRANT COORDINATOR, IF APPLICABLE, TO DETERMINE THAT REQUIRED CR ITERIA ARE MET.

HESSTON COLLEGE EVALUATES EACH STUDENT FOR FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID USING THE INFORMATION ON THE FAFSA FORM AS WELL AS OTHER APPLICATION MATERIALS COMPLETED FOR THEIR INSTITUTIONAL AID OFFERINGS. STUDENTS MUST MEET ALL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION GUIDELINES TO RECEIVE FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID, INCLUDING LOANS. SUCH GUIDELINES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS, ATTENDANCE, NUMBER OF HOURS, AND A CLEAN FINANCIAL AID HISTORY. STUDENTS MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR MERIT-BASED AID AND SOME MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. IN ADDITION TO BOTH NEED- AND MERIT-BASED QUALIFICATIONS, STUDENTS MUST MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN AID ELEMENTS. ALL DETERMINATIONS ARE MADE BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IN CONJUNCTION WITH ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS, ATHLETIC DEPARTMENTS, ADMISSIONS STAFF, AND DEVELOPMENT/ADVANCEMENT STAFF.

EMU awards student financial assistance grants & scholarships to eligible students. Use of funds is monitored by the EMU Financial Aid Department and tracked by applying aid to the student account to offset charges to tuition and fees.

ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION WAIVERS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' SUMMIT CHRISTIAN COLLEGE ACCOUNTS AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.
Grants received are applied directly to student tuition invoices. The grants are used to gap the bridge between financial aid and the full amount of tuition due.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE OFFERED BASED ON MANUAL AND/OR ELECTRONIC VERIFICATION OF ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA. THE SYSTEM DISBURSEMENT OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT OCCURS ONLY AFTER GLOBAL AND ITEM TYPE SPECIFIC DISBURSEMENT ELIGIBILITY RULES ARE MET. UPON DISBURSEMENT, PAYMENT ALLOCATION RULES IN THE SYSTEM ALLOCATE THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO APPROPRIATE PREDEFINED CHARGES. AFTER DISBURSEMENT AUDITS ARE DONE AT VARIOUS TIME INTERVALS TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY.

GRANTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE COLLEGE MONITORS STUDENT TUITION ACCOUNTS FOR ANY STUDENT WHO RECEIVED A SCHOLARSHIP OR TUITION CREDIT. THE BURSAR'S OFFICE AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ENSURE THAT STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS OR TUITION CREDITS MAINTAIN FULL-TIME OR PART-TIME STUDENT STATUS AND MEET ALL OTHER REQUIREMENTS, AS REQUIRED BY THE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIP, SO THAT THE FUNDS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.
PAY-IT FORWARD SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON A STUDENT'S STATEMENT OF NEED.
ALL GRANTS ARE USED TO PAY TUITION AT THE COLLEGE.
THE UNIVERSITY COMPLIES WITH ALL CONTRACTUAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS WHEN DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS.

Most grants and scholarhsips administered by Bellin College are awarded based on financial need; some have additional eligibility requirements set by donors or other entities. The bursar and director of financial aid reconcile awards/payments on a regular basis to ensure accuracy on students' accounts.
Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 -Students seeking financial aid must file a FAFSA to determine their eligibility and need for grant and scholarship aid.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY EACH SCHOLARSHIP AND DETERMINED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE.
All assistance to individuals is in the form of financial aid, grants, scholarships and tuition discounts awarded to students. Assistance is applied directly to the student's account balance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Description Of Procedure For Monitoring Use Of Grant Funds
ExplntnTxt: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY IS NOT A "GRANTMAKER" PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION, AND PURPOSE FOR TAX-EXEMPTION, RELATES TO EDUCATION AND RESEARCH. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF THESE MISSION-related ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF THE FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO TWO CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID - THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED EITHER ON FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT; THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE) DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. VARIOUS ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR MERIT-BASED AID; and (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS - CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY IS NOT A "GRANTMAKER" PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION, AND PURPOSE FOR TAX-EXEMPTION, RELATES TO EDUCATION AND RESEARCH. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF THESE MISSION-related ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF THE FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO TWO CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID - THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED EITHER ON FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT; THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE) DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. VARIOUS ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR MERIT-BASED AID; and (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS - CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY.

GRANTS CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA AND ELIGIBILITY EACH SEMESTER FOR EVERY STUDENT. WITHDRAWALS FROM CLASSES REQUIRE THE STUDENT TO HAVE A FORM SIGNED BY THE ACADEMIC OFFICE, THE BUSINESS OFFICE, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE AMOUNT OF SCHOLARSHIPS GRANTED IS PRO-RATED BASED ON FEDERAL REGULATIONS.

GRANT MONITORING PROCESS Financial aid awards are disbursed to students based on the general criteria for institutional financial aid. GPA and enrollment are monitored to ensure these criteria are met.

An institutional agreement is signed between McMaster and the grantee stating that the grantee institution is responsible for following the policies, procedures and regulations of the granting agency. At a minimum, an annual statement of expenditures is provided to McMaster and is reviewed for ineligible/non-compliance issues. McMaster can require an audit at any time, if necessary.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS CONTROLS IN PLACE TO MONITOR THE USE OF ALL GRANT FUNDS. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE UNIVERSITY. THE DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENTS REVIEW OVERALL USE OF SCHOLARHSIP AND OTHER GRANT FUNDS TO ENSURE THAT THE RECIPIENTS ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THE FUNDS. ALL FUNDS ISSUED TO THE STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD. SINCE THE STUDENTS HAVE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS, THE UNIVERSITY HAS NO NEED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS ONCE THEY ARE ISSUED.

Master's College and Seminary awards financial aid grants to students in accordance with the College's institutional financial aid policies. All scholarships are awarded to current students of the institution, thus enabling the institution to track their academic performance and use of all scholarship funds.
COLLEGETRACKS STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE GRANTS THROUGH COLLEGE TRACKS PARTICIPATE IN OUR COLLEGE SUCCESS PROGRAM, THROUGH WHICH WE MONITOR THEIR ACADEMIC AND OTHER PROGRESS THROUGH COLLEGE.
ALL EXPENDITURES USING GRANT FUNDS REQUIRE PROPER APPROVAL PER THE GUIDELINES SPECIFIED IN THE GRANT. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE WITH THE GRANT GUIDELINES.

SCHEDULE I, PART III- SCHOLARSHIPS/STUDENT AID GRANTS - INCLUDES PRIMARILY ROOM AND BOARD, BOOKS AND SUPPLIES ASSISTANCE. THE AMOUNT OF TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS/STUDENT AID FOR THE YEAR WAS 2,120,834.
Student financial aid is credited to the individual student accounts and their net balances are monitored by the Business Office.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROVIDED AS A CREDIT TO THE STUDENT TO COVER CHARGES OF TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD, AND OTHER FEES RELATED TO THE COST OF ATTENDANCE.
Scholarships

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ARE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF NEED AND ELIGIBILITY FOR SPECIFIC AWARDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ANY DONOR STIPULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS AND FOR MONITORING ONGOING ELIGIBILITY (E.G. MAINTENANCE OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS).
GRANTS ARE ISSUED TO COVER THE EDUCATION COST OF THE WCMS PROGRAMS.

STUDENTS FILL OUT A FAFSA TO SEE WHAT GOVERNMENT AID THEY QUALIFY FOR. THE DIRECTOR FOR FINANCIAL AID AWARDS THE GOVERNMENT AID BASED ON TITLE IV RULES AND REGULATIONS AND AID FROM THE COLLEGE BASED ON COLLEGE POLICY. RECORDS ON FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE MAINTAINED IN STUDENT FILES. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IS AUDITED ANNUALLY.

Each year Albany Law School awards a number of merit and diversity scholarships funded from restricted and unrestricted endowment funds, annual giving by alumni and friends and other sources. The Admissions Committee awards the scholarships to first year students in the form of three scholarships in varying amounts. Financial Aid personnel, in conjunction with Development and Business Office personnel, are responsible for monitoring compliance with restrictions associated with the endowment funds. All scholarships are merit-based and awarded on the basis of academic promise and individual characteristics that strengthen the applicant pool. The Admissions Committee also offers merit-based scholarships to students from diverse backgrounds including those minorities who historically have been under-represented in the legal profession. A scholarship may be retained from year to year without re-application upon achievement of grades set forth as conditions of the award. Monitoring of continued awarding for second and third year students is performed by the Financial Aid Office in conjunction with the Registrar's Office.

AFTER AN APPLICATION IS SUBMITTED BY THE STUDENT, FINANCIAL AID EVALUATES IT FOR NEED AND BASED ON THEIR ENROLLED COURSES, AND THIS IS RE-EVALUATED EACH YEAR AS NEED AND ENROLLMENT INDICATE. THE UNIVERSITY DOES MONITOR THE USE OF THE STUDENT AID AND IT IS APPLIED TO THEIR STUDENT BILLING ACCOUNT IN THE UNIVERSITY'S SIS (STUDENT INFORMATION SYSTEM).

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MAINTAINS RECORDS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED TO NCU STUDENTS IN THE POWERFAIDS DATABASE. THIS SYSTEM TRACKS ENROLLMENT AND AID ELIGIBILITY AND ENSURES THAT STUDENTS ARE NOT AWARDED AID THAT EXCEEDS THEIR COST TO ATTEND COLLEGE. IN ADDITION THESE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ALWAYS APPLIED TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT IN OUR ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TO ENSURE AWARDED FUNDS GO FIRST TO COVER TUITION AND OTHER INSTITUTIONAL CHARGES.
THE FOUNDATION MONITORS ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS BY ASSESSING STUDENT RECORDS, FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS FOR AWARDS.

A STUDENT MUST COMPLETE A FAFSA APPLICATION FOR THE GIVEN ACADEMIC YEAR. THE STUDENT MUST BE ENROLLED IN A DEGREE SEEKING PROGRAM; NON MATRICULATED STUDENTS ARE NOT ELIGIBLE FOR FINANCIAL AID FUNDS. STUDENTS MUST ENROLL FOR AT LEAST 6 CREDITS TO RECEIVE ANY FEDERAL FUNDS, EXCEPT STUDENTS WHO QUALIFY FOR THE PELL GRANT PROGRAM. UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN A CUMULATIVE GPA OF 2.0 AND GRADUATE STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN A CUMULATIVE GPA OF 3.0 EACH SEMESTER.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID SERVICES AWARDS FINANCIAL AID IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE HIGHER EDUCATION ACT. FEDERAL AND STATE AWARDING GUIDELINES ARE USED IN AWARDING STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS ARE REVIEWED ON A BI-WEEKLY BASIS TO ENSURE THAT ALL STUDENTS ARE CURRENTLY ENROLLED ACCORDING TO APPROPRIATE GUIDELINES. A QUALITY CONTROL CHECK IS IN PLACE IN THAT A FILE AUDIT IS PERFORMED OF A RANDOM SAMPLE OF FILES TO ENSURE THAT PROPER PROCEDURES ARE BEING FOLLOWED. AN ANNUAL AUDIT IS PERFORMED BY AN OUTSIDE COMPANY TO ENSURE THAT THERE ARE NO GROSS VIOLATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON ESTABLISHED FEDERAL AND COLLEGE POLICIES. AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNT AT THE COLLEGE AS CREDITS TO TUITION AND OTHER FEES.

To ensure our grants and scholarships are used for the proper purposes the Edgewood College Financial Aid Office performs regular maintenance and reconciliations with our business office monitoring that all funds awarded to a particular student are being properly credited to their student account. Any changes or adjustments to original awards that affect grant and scholarship funding are made within Powerfaids, the financial aid software program. These changes to awards are electronically transmitted at least weekly to the business office. The resulting changes are then displayed on their student account. The Financial Aid Office has the ability to generate reports as needed for monitoring and reconciliation purposes. These reports are compared to reports generated by the Business Office to ensure that all program amounts are accurately reflected. Additionally, we have a yearly audit performed by an outside accounting firm guaranteeing we are staying in compliance with all federal, state and institutional policies and procedures as well as assuring funding is being used as intended.

Gordon College awards three types of grants/scholarships: merit scholarships, need-based grants and endowment funded restricted scholarships. Merit scholarships are awarded based on the incoming student's academic criteria determined by the Admissions Office. These scholarships are renewed annually by verification of the Registrar's Office that cumulative GPA requirements are met. Need-based grants are awarded based on the student's determined financial need. We determine financial need using information provided by the FAFSA. We practice level-funding of the need-based grants to future years unless there is a significant change in determined financial need. Endowment funded restricted scholarships are awarded based on criteria established by donors. The criteria information on specific eligible students is provided by the Registrar, Admissions and Financial Aid Offices. Students are evaluated annually to verify they continue to meet the donor criteria for an endowment award.

MERIT AND ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON PREVIOUS AND CURRENT ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. OTHER INTERNAL AND ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SPECIFIC TO THE SCHOLARSHIP. SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID AND THE FINANCE OFFICE OF THE COLLEGE.

All funds are awarded through the college's financial aid office and posted directly to the students' accounts by the student accounts office. Students may be awarded grant funds on the basis of academic achievement and/or financial need. In each case the student can retain eligibility for funding for as many as eight semesters as a full-time student, provided the student meets the renewal criteria such as grade point average and grade procession as outlined in the student handbook. An individual student may not receive more than the cost of tuition from the institutional grant funds. A reconciliation is done regularly between the two departments/systems to ensure accuracy and proper use of the funds. In addition, an annual audit is performed by an outside accounting firm to review compliance with all federal, state and institutional policies and procedures.
Menlo College requires financial aid applicants submit evidence of eligibility and maintains ongoing records of attendance and scholastic achievements by all recipients.

ALL GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE THAT ARE PROVIDED BY THOMAS AQUINAS COLLEGE ARE PART OF A NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM THAT ASSISTS STUDENTS WITH THE COST OF TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD. BESIDES GRANTS, THE ONLY OTHER ASSISTANCE OFFERED IS A NEED-BASED EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, THE GRANTEE'S ELIGIBILITY FOR THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA USED TO AWARD THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE. ALL GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE CAREFULLY MONITORED BY THOMAS AQUINAS COLLEGE. THE AMOUNTS ARE DISBURSED DIRECTLY INTO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD, AND CONSEQUENTLY, THE COLLEGE HAS FULL CONTROL OVER HOW THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE USED.

Emergency Aid: Students are required to substantiate a legitimate need for benevolence before money is awarded. No attempt to verify the use of the money is made.Tuition assistance: Tuition is discounted to apply aid.

POEC gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admissions documentation by certain deadlines and apply with good academic standing.

KILIAN COMMUNITY COLLEGE AWARDS ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ON THE FINANCIAL AID AWARD LETTER. THE BUSINESS OFFICE CREDITS THE STUDENT ACCOUNT WITH THE SCHOLARSHIP. THESE FUNDS ARE THEN USED TO ASSIST WITH TUITION AND FEES ON STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.

THE SCHOOL'S STUDENTS SCHOLARSHIPS (GRANTS) ARE NON-CASH TUITION DISCOUNTS APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND CANNOT BE DIVERTED FROM INTENDED USES. THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS REPORTED ABOVE WAS COMPILED FROM SCHOLARSHIP DISBURSEMENT RECORDS FOR THE REPORTED FISCAL YEAR. THE SCHOOL'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH TYPE OF AWARD.

The Financial Aid Office maintains a database of all students, their eligibility for grant funds determined through FASFA and other analytic procedures, the amount awarded and accepted by each student, and documentation of verifying the data. The College also has an A-133 audit performed each year in addition to the financial statement audit.
The organization maintains a policy and procedures manual which outlines the organization's policy on awarding federal, state, and institutional assistance to students.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES: AFTER STUDENT HAS BEEN ACCEPTED, THEY MUST FILE A FAFSA. THE UNIVERSITY CONSIDERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS, FEDERAL GRANTS AND STATE ELIGIBILITY IN THAT RESPECTIVE ORDER. IF THE STUDENT NEEDS FUTHER ASSISTANCE, THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS FEDERAL LOANS, COLLEGE GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. FINANCIAL AID BASED ON NEED IS AWARDED ON FAFSA CALCULATIONS AND THE RESULTING FINANCIAL AID THAT IS TO BE MET. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GPA, CLASS RANK AND STANDARD TEST SCORES. NEED-BASED GRANTS CAN BE ALLOCATED TO RETURNING STUDENTS BASED ON PREVIOUS YEARS AS LONG AS FINANCIAL NEED IS STILL PRESENT. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS CONTINUE BASED ON THE STUDENT'S CUMULATIVE GPA AT THE END OF THE YEAR.

THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, ADMINISTERS A WIDE VARIETY OF FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. ITS MAJOR OBJECTIVE IS THE EQUITABLE DISTRIBUTION OF FINANCIAL AID TO ALL STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION SERVICES IN ORDER TO HELP STUDENTS FINANCE THEIR EDUCATION. RECIPIENTS ARE DETERMINED BY ACADEMIC MERIT, AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TOWARD TUITION CHARGES ONLY AND RECIPIENTS MUST MAINTAIN CERTAIN ELIGIBLITY REQUIREMENTS TO RECEIVE THEM.
HAWAII TOKAI INTERNATIONAL COLLEGE GIVES TUITION WAIVERS TO STUDENTS THAT QUALIFY AND ACCOUNT FOR SUCH THROUGH LETTERS TO THE STUDENTS THAT RECEIVE THESE WAIVERS.
SCHOLARSHIP APPROVAL AND DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
COLLEGE ADVISING CORPS CONDUCTS MONITORING VISITS WITH THE PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS.

Grant funds are monitored through an electronic packaging program for all students. This electronic program determines the eligibility for federal, state and institutional grant funding against a series of pre-established eligibility criteria. Once the program determines each student's eligibility for federal, state and institutional grant funding. The information is also checked by a member of the Student Financial Planning staff.

The College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College based on need and/or merit. The College monitors students' files to ensure that the student receives necessary financial assistance based on grades, course of study and financial need. All funds granted are required to be used to defray the costs of attendance; funds may not be spent on discretionary items.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE MONITORED COLLABORATIVELY BY THE OFFICE OF THE REGISTRAR, OFFICE OF THE BURSAR, FINANCIAL PLANNING, AND THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE TO VERIFY ELIGIBILITY, APPROPRIATE SELECTION CRITERIA AND APPLICATION OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS. FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.
The university has a specific department related to student financial aid that tracks all scholarships and grant funds disbursed to students.

All Federal financial aid administered by Barnard College is based on demonstrated financial need as determined by the Federal Methodology formula. However institutional aid is determined using a Barnard Need Analysis formula which takes into consideration all sources of income and all assets. Barnard does not provide merit scholarships. The College believes that the primary responsibility for financing educational cost rests with each student's family, and all college aid is supplementary to family resources. Once need has been established, Barnard makes every effort to meet the need of all eligible students with a combination of grants, loans and employment opportunities. A student who is admitted to Barnard with financial aid cannot be guaranteed college grants for future years. Awards are for one academic year only. A student can receive Barnard aid for a maximum of eight semesters. Each semester a student is enrolled is counted towards the eight semesters of eligibility whether or not aid was received. No financial aid is given for summer study. If a student has room in her academic year financial aid package and has not already borrowed the maximum loans, these funds may be borrowed during the academic year to be used for classes the following semester. For financial statement purposes, the Pell grant awards of $ 2,145,071 are excluded.

Santa Barbara & Ventura Colleges of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. These scholarships are dependent upon factors such as alumni recommendations, academic standing, and other criteria related to admission/participation in the program. Santa Barbara & Ventura Colleges of Law maintains records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS OFFERED AT GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BANKING (GSBC): 1. GSBC OFFERS GENERAL SCHOLARSHIPS THROUGH VARIOUS STATE BANKER ASSOCIATIONS IN WHICH CANDIDATES FILL OUT A GENERAL SCHOLARSHIP FORM (INCLUDED) WITH THE SUPPORT OF A SUPERVISOR AND THE SCHOLARSHIP IS REVIEWED BY THE STATE ASSOCIATION AND GSBC. IN MOST CASES, ONE GENERAL SCHOLARSHIP PER STATE WHERE IT IS OFFERED IS AWARDED TO A NEW STUDENT EACH YEAR. 2. GSBC ALSO OFFER SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO TOP GRADUATES OF THE INTERMEDIATE LEVEL STATE ASSOCIATION SCHOOLS SUCH AS THE KS/NE ADVANCED SCHOOL OF BANKING; IOWA SCHOOL OF BANKING; MISSOURI SCHOOL OF BANK MANAGEMENT; ETC. IF THE TOP GRADUATE DOES NOT ACCEPT, SOMETIMES IT IS OPENED UP FOR ALL GRADUATES TO APPLY OR THE SECOND-HIGHEST GRADUATE, THIRD HIGHEST, AND SO FORTH.

PRE-AWARD SUBRECIPIENT MONITOR: Federal awards are identified by informing each subrecipient of CFDA title and number, award name and number, award year, and name of Federal agency. If any of this information is not available, the pass-through entity shall provide the best information available to describe the Federal award. The subrecipient is advised of requirements imposed by governing laws, regulations, and provisions of contracts or grant agreements and supplemental requirements imposed by the pass-through entity. The subrecipients' activities are monitored to ensure awards are used for authorized purposes in compliance with laws, regulations, and the provisions of contracts or grant agreements and performance goals are achieved. Assurance is ascertained that any sub recipient expending $750,000 or more in Federal awards during the subrecipient's fiscal year must meet the audit requirements of Uniform Grant Guidance (formerly OMB A-133). A management decision on audit findings must be issued within six months after receipt of the subrecipient's audit report and ensure that the subrecipient takes appropriate and timely corrective action. A determination is made as to whether subrecipient audits necessitate adjustment of the pass-through entity's own records. Each subrecipient is required to permit the pass-through entity and auditors to have access to the records and financial statements as necessary for the pass-through entity to comply with this part. POST-AWARD SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING: The Principal Investigator (PI) or Program Director (PD) is responsible for monitoring the activities. The subrecipient submits progress reports, technical reports and other deliverables to the PI/PD by specified due dates. The PI/PD is responsible for forwarding copies of the subrecipient's report(s) to the Office of Sponsored Programs and Research (OSPR). Subrecipient invoices submitted to the university must contain the following information: invoice must be on subcontractor's letterhead, date of invoice, invoice number, period of performance covered by the invoice, itemized description of services and backup documentation, current period costs, including cost sharing, cumulative project costs, sub recipient contact person with respect to invoice, invoice must be signed by an authorized official of the subcontractor, invoice must contain a certification that all payments requested are for appropriate purposes and in accordance with the agreements set forth in the application and award documents. The PI/PD is responsible for reviewing and approving invoices from subrecipient(s) for adherence to the budget. The signature of the PI/PD on the invoice indicates that the review has taken place and that the invoice adheres to budget. Grant Accounting reviews the subrecipient's invoice(s) for the following: period of performance is within the contract period, appropriate invoice format and level of detail, signatures of the PI/PD, certification of signature by authorized subrecipient representatives, funds are available in contract, and cost share documentation is provide, if applicable. Grant Accounting is responsible for ensuring that sub recipients that expend $750,000 or more of Federal funds each fiscal year submit an Audit Certification Letter. The following is required to close out a subrecipient award: receipt of final invoice, receipt of cost share documentation, if applicable, time and effort certifications, final progress and technical reports, annual audit certification letter. Grant Accounting is responsible for tracking payments made to individuals or organizations and where payments are made when out of the US as required by the Schedules F and I - Form 990. EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE: Educational assistance is awarded based on financial need and merit. Need based assistance is awarded after review of the student's FAFSA, tax return information, W-2 statements, and other relevant financial documents. Students are required to maintain satisfactory academic progress in order to continue to be eligible for need based assistance. Students' Grade Point Averages and earned units are reviewed each academic year to ensure satisfactory academic progress is achieved. Merit based educational assistance is awarded to students via Committee. Students who are awarded merit based assistance are required to maintain satisfactory academic progress in accordance with the terms of the assistance received. Need and merit based educational assistance are funded directly to the student's accounts receivable balance to offset tuition, fees, and room and board. Any resulting refunds are issued to the student. Students may be granted research awards by their academic departments and in such cases work with faculty advisors who monitor the research performed by the student.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Baldwin Wallace University awards scholarships and makes need-based financial aid grants only to its own enrolled students. The awards constitute part of the cost of attending. Additional need-based aid usually consists of Federal Direct Student Loans and College Work Study for jobs on campus. The Student Financial Aid Office makes need-based grants on the basis of demonstrated financial need using nationally accepted forms and methods. The same office awards merit scholarships using Baldwin Wallace criteria. The University disburses the grants as credits to student receivable accounts, offsetting amounts billed for tuition and other fees.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ACCORDING TO THE UNIVERSITY'S ESTABLISHED ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA AND REGULATIONS.

Grants or assistance provided is for scholarships and grants to Simpson College students which are applied directly to the student's tuition charges. The Office of Financial Assistance awards scholarships and grants to students based on a variety of different criteria for each scholarship.

Need Scholarships: Manhattan College awards grants-in-aid to accepted students who demonstrate financial need. These awards are renewed annually and adjusted in line with changes on the FAFSA. These awards are given for a maximum of four years (eight semesters). Grant recipients must maintain satisfactory academic progress. Full time enrollment is necessary to receive grant. Academic Scholarships: Eligibility is based on exceptional SAT or ACT scores, secondary school grade point average, and rank in class. The amount of the Scholarship is determined at the time of admission and is offered for four years (eight semesters maximum) provided the student remains eligible. Athletic Scholarships: Manhattan College has available a strictly-budgeted fund to offer grants-in-aid to students who, by the possession of certain athletic skills can add to the community spirit and morale of the campus. The College firmly states that recipients must come to Manhattan as students, with their first interest in studies. They must meet the same entrance requirements as other students and must maintain satisfactory academic progress. Manhattan adheres to and endorses the principles and policies of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, Eastern College Athletic Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Graduate Scholarships are awarded as part of grants, grad assistance or by departments. HEOP Scholarships are awarded as part of the New York State Program. Endowment scholarships are awarded based upon the donors written restrictions.

The Vice President for Finance collects grant award letters and instructions from the granting agencies of the BCU grant managers. The Vice President for Finance keeps a fiscal file for each grant, including award letters, instructions, annual accounting records, and financial reports submitted to the grantors. Either the Vice President for Finance or the grant manager submits reports to agencies, depending on the grant. The Vice President for Finance creates a budget for each grant in the grants fund, based on award letters and input from the BCU grant managers. If the grant allows, grant managers may request budget transfers within their grant, which the Vice President for Finance or the Assistant Vice President for Finance enter in Datatel. The grant manager signs off o expenditures for the grant. The Vice President for Finance reviews all grant expenditures monthly, with more in-depth review as needed for reporting to grantors. The Vice President for Finance reconciles grant expenditures annually for both BCU fiscal year and the grant fiscal year, if different. Financial aid grants are approved and reported by the Financial Aid department. Checks for grant revenues are received in the Business Office; some agencies mail them to the grant managers, who then turn them in to the Business Office for deposit. Some agencies pay BCU through direct deposit into BCU checking accounts. The Vice President for Finance draws down federal grant funds electronically through the online G5 system; drawdowns are usually done monthly.

LIPSCOMB UNIVERSITY HAS AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ITS FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ITS FINANCIAL AID AWARDING PROCESS (CALLED THE OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AUDIT). IN ADDITION, FINANCIAL AID COUNSELORS ATTEND CONFERENCES AND TRAINING SESSIONS ON FINANCIAL AID AWARDING POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND CONTROLS.
THE UNIVERSITY FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS GRANTS BASED ON DOE TITLE IV REGULATIONS AND UNIVERSITY APPROVED POLICIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: All grants are in the form of scholarships and are applied toward the cost of tuition only.
Current student financial aid records are verified and compared with eligibility requirements before grants are awarded.

THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY CLEARY UNIVERSITY ARE USED TO PAY TUITION AND FEE CHARGES ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO MONITOR WHETHER RECIPIENTS REMAIN STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY THROUGH THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE, AND CLASS ATTENDANCE TAKEN BY PROFESSORS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ACCORDING TO THE CRITERIA IDENTIFIED FOR INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS. APPLICATIONS ARE RECEIVED FROM STUDENTS AND REVIEWED BY THE RESPECTIVE COMMITTEE, EITHER THE FACULTY OR THE ADMISSIONS COMMITTEE TO DETERMINE AWARDS. THE MINDFULNESS INITIATIVE FUNDS SUPPORT ONGOING RESEARCH AND TRAINING, AND PRESENTATION OF THAT RESEARCH AT NATIONAL CONFERENCES. THE FACULTY MEMBER RESPONSIBLE SUBMITS PLANS FOR MINDFULNESS RELATED ACTIVITIES TO THE PRESIDENT AND REQUESTS REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES RELATED TO THESE PLANNED ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE MINDFULNESS INITIATIVE TO THE PRESIDENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The organization has rules in place to ensure that scholarship aid provided to students is used for authorized purposes. Additional detail is available upon request.

Within the limits of available resources, the College makes every effort to make financial aid opportunities available to needy and academically eligible students. Traditional-age students must be enrolled in a full-time undergraduate degree program to be considered for College academic scholarships, grants and/or need-based financial aid. With the exception of some academic scholarships, students who wish to apply for grants, loans or work-study submit the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Awards are considered on the basis of financial need and/or a student's academic profile. Awards are packaged using a combination of grants and scholarships, loans and work-study assignments. Students must be in good academic standing and achieve the minimum standards of academic progress. We use College Board's Powerfaids software to manage our financial aid database and awarding procedures.
THE UNIVERSITY HAS POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND COMPLIES WITH THE FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR AWARDING STUDENT AID.
GRANTS ARE LIMITED TO RESTRICTED SCHOLARSHIPS THAT CAN ONLY BE APPLIED TO USCS TUITION COSTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND MERIT

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS ANY EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS OVER THEIR CHARGES, THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE COLLEGE HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE COLLEGE'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE COLLEGE'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.
Selection of students is based on established criteria of each scholarship fund and students are awarded scholarships on account through financial aid.
The grants are distributed to the student accounts are payments to offset tuition costs.
College Financial Aid is administered and awarded for students attending Roanoke College by the college's Financial Aid office using the college's policies and procedures.

DRAKE UNIVERSITY HAS EMPLOYEES DEDICATED TO POST-AWARD REVIEW AND COMPLIANCE FOR ALL FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE GRANTS RECEIVED. IN ADDITION, DRAKE RECEIVES AN A-133 AUDIT ON AN ANNUAL BASIS FROM OUR EXTERNAL AUDIT FIRM. OUR FY13 A-133 AUDIT EXPRESSED AN UNQUALIFIED OPINION WITH NO FINDINGS, NO SIGNIFICANT DEFICIENCIES IN INTERNAL CONTROL, AND NO INSTANCES OF MATERIAL NONCOMPLIANCE.

GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE MASTER OF DIVINITY PROGRAM AND ARE CHOSEN BASED ON NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS COMPLETED IN THE DEGREE PROGRAM, NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS TAKEN EACH TERM, AND FINANCIAL NEED.

The school's Financial Aid Office plus the Financial Services Office follow detailed procedures which insure the federal grant regulations are followed. These offices are audited each year by an independent external CPA firm and reported thereon to the federal government.
THE ORGANIZATION ONLY GAVE NONCASH TUITION REDUCTION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS SET CRITERIA FOR SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS.
Scholarships are determined by FAFSA requirements, and need base.

STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID. THEIR APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED BY A COLLEGE COMMITTEE. AWARDS ARE BASED ON A COMBINATION OF NEED AND ACADEMICS. FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION AND FEES.
There is also a follow up process during the quarter to assure student is making satisfactory academic progress before additional financial aid is rewarded.

The College donated its KCAM equipment and other assets to another exempt organization in FY16. The College campus had moved from Glennallen, AK to Palmer, AK, yet the related radio station assets remained in Glenallen. It was decided by the board to relieve the College of these assets by donating to another exempt organization in the Glennallen area. The book value includes assets, depreciation, and related expenses for the divestiture of the assets.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The need-based grant is funded by Alaska Bible College and utilized to assist students with financial need. The qualify, a student must be enrolled full-time (12+ credits) in a degree or certificate program, must maintain a 2.0 GPA, and must maintain a current financial account with the Business Office. Students complete and submit an application along with financial information to help a committee determine each student's financial need. Decisions are made by the committee and awards are given after the 6-week grade check each semester.

THE UNIVERSITY DETERMINES THE ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH STUDENT'S NEEDS AND THE AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE STUDENT'S CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE THE ASSISTANCE.

NORTHWEST NAZARENE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF ITS GRANT FUNDS AS REQUIRED BY THE INDIVIDUAL GRANT PROGRAMS AND DONOR CRITERIA ESTABLISHED AT THE TIME OF THE ORIGINAL DONATION. THESE ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE ANNUAL AUDITING PROCESS AS WELL AS THROUGH FEDERAL AND STATE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. ISIR/FAFSA AND HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS SHOWING ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE STUDENT'S FILE FOR A PERIOD OF 7 YEARS AFTER THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS OR FINISHES THEIR PROGRAMS. GRANT AMOUNTS APPEAR ON THE AWARD LETTER IN THE FILE AS WELL AS ON THE INDIVIDUAL'S FINANCIAL AID RECORD IN THE DATABASE.

ALL GRANT ACTIVITY IS REQUIRED TO MEET THE SPECIFIC STANDARDS AND STIPULATIONS OF THE GRANTOR AND OPERATE WITHIN THE ORGANIZATION'S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. GRANT REVENUE AND EXPENDITURES ARE MONITORED AND FUNDS ARE DRAWN DOWN ON A MONTHLY BASIS. INTERNAL REPORTS AND AWARD LEVELS ARE REVIEWED PRIOR TO EACH DRAW TO DETERMINE IF CASH SHOULD BE DRAWN FOR INDIVIDUAL GRANTS. FINALLY, THE COLLEGE UNDERGOES AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ITS FEDERAL AWARDS UNDER THE GUIDELINES OF OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

FUNDS RECEIVED FROM THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH FROM LEGISLATION THAT CREATED THE MERC TRUST FUND (PMAP/PGAMC DISTRIBUTION) THAT PROVIDES REMUNERATION FOR THOSE FACILITIES THAT SERVED AS CLINICAL TRAINING SITES FOR THE COLLEGE'S NURSE PRACTITIONER AND CLINICAL NURSE SPECIALIST STUDENTS DURING THE 2013-2014 ACADEMIC YEAR. THE AMOUNTS PAID FROM THE FUNDS RECEIVED FROM THE MERC LEGISLATION TO EACH ORGANIZATION LISTED IN PART II IS BASED ON THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS THEY HAD AND THE LENGTH OF TIME THEY SPENT AT EACH RESPECTIVE FACILITY. TRAINING SITES MUST ALSO HAVE A CURRENT ACTIVE MEDICAL ASSISTANCE ENROLLMENT STATUS IN MINNESOTA.

ALL STUDENT AID AWARD LETTERS ARE PREPARED BY LINDENWOOD COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. EACH AWARD LETTER HAS A STATEMENT OF CONDITIONS AND IS SIGNED BY THE STUDENT. THE BUSINESS OFFICE POSTS ALL AID TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR ACADEMIC USAGE. BOTH THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITOR THESE FUNDS.

The Chicago School - Washington, D.C., Inc. gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship.
