Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admission documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1,300 (test taken prior to August 1, 2011) or a combined GRE score of 314 (test taken on or after August 1, 2011). The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and adminstrative activities within the department or office.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN ITS PROGRAMS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON STUDENT ACHIEVEMENTS IN ACADEMICS, PERFORMING ARTS, AND ATHLETICS. TO BE CONSIDERED FOR SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE, STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR ADMISSION, SUBMIT ACADEMIC TRANSCIPTS OF PRIOR EDUCATIONAL WORK, SUBMIT TEST SCORES (ACT/SAT), AND SUBMIT AN APPLICATION FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM. SOME SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS OR CERTIFICATIONS BY THIRD PARTIES. ACADEMIC PROGRESS OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS IS MONITERED, AND THEY MUST EARN A MINIMUM AMOUNT OF COLLEGE CREDITS AND A MINIMUM GPA EACH SEMESTER IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY.

Federal and State Grants are awarded based on Federal title IV and state higher educational compliance requirements. Institutional Scholarships are awarded based upon parameters established by each endowment fund and are monitored by a university scholarship committee. Scholarships are awarded without respect to race, creed & color.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: WHEN STUDENTS ARE AWARDED A TUITION SCHOLARSHIP, THE COUNCIL SENDS THE MONEY DIRECTLY TO THE SCHOOL THE STUDENT IS ATTENDING WITH INSTRUCTIONS THAT IT IS TO BE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION. IF THE STUDENT DROPS THE CLASS OR OTHERWISE DOES NOT ATTEND, THE REFUND IS RETURNED TO THE COUNCIL. THIS PROCESS ENSURES THE SCHOLARSHIP IS USED FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: GRANTS ISSUED BY THE SEMINARY ARE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS FOR THEIR EDUCATIONAL ENDEAVORS AT THE SEMINARY. SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE BASED ON DONOR INTENT AND INTERNAL GUIDELINES, SUCH AS ACADEMIC ELIGIBILITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANT APPLICATIONS ARE KEPT IN STORAGE FOR SEVEN YEARS. PREVIOUSLY UNFUNDED APPLICANTS FOR GRANT MONIES FROM BEREA COLLEGE APPALACHIAN FUND (BCAF) FOLLOW CRITERIA AND A FORMAT WHICH ARE CLEARLY STATED ON THE PROGRAM WEBSITE: HTTP://WWW.BEREA.EDU/APPALACHIANFUND/APPLYINGFORGRANT.ASP. PREVIOUSLY FUNDED APPLICANTS MUST PROVIDE A DETAILED REPORT ON THE USE OF THE PREVIOUS YEAR'S GRANT FUNDING. THIS FORMAT AND CRITERIA ARE LOCATED ON THE SAME LOCATION OF THE BCAF WEBSITE. IN ADDITION, THE BCAF SPONSORS A GRANTEE CONFERENCE EACH SPRING WHEN ALL GRANTEES FOR THAT YEAR MEET AND CONDUCT PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS OF THEIR GRANT FUNDED WORK. THE BCAF IS IN REGULAR CONTACT WITH GRANTEES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR, VISITING EACH NEW GRANTEE AND REPEAT GRANTEES WHERE POSSIBLE. The staff of Grow Appalachia, including the director and two assistant directors, all individually review funding proposals from the potential partner sites for quality of programming, outreach activities and budget line items. This staff then meet as a group and discuss each proposal and either approve them as submitted, reject them out of hand, accept them conditionally asking for clarification or request more information to allow a sound decision. When the information requests are met the staff meet again and either accept or reject the proposal. Grow Appalachia also has an advisory board consisting of college and non-college members who are kept informed of Grow Appalachia's activities and program direction and who then offer advice and counsel for the program. FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL AND OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON FINANCIAL INFORMATION GAINED FROM THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) THAT IS COMPLETED EACH YEAR. A THIRD-PARTY SOFTWARE VENDOR PROVIDES THE FEDERAL REGULATIONS BY WHICH GRANTS ARE GIVEN. THE FAFSA INFORMATION COMES FROM ELECTRONIC FILES WHICH ARE PASSWORD PROTECTED.ALL STUDENT APPLICATIONS FOR GRANTS ARE STORED ELECTRONICALLY AND ARE PASSWORD PROTECTED. DISBURSEMENTS ARE REVIEWED DAILY TO INSURE ACCURACY.

PELL GRANT ORIGINATION, CERTIFICATION, AND RECONCILIATION IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE DIRECTOR & ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS. CAMS PRODUCES PELL GRANT ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT RECORDS, WHICH ARE SENT VIA EDCONNECT THROUGH THE COMMON ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT (COD) PROCESS. STATEMENT OF ACCOUNTS FILES ARE RECONCILED MONTHLY BETWEEN CAMS, COD AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE DIRECTOR & ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE CAL GRANT PROGRAM. THE WEBGRANTS ROSTER FROM THE CALIFORNIA STUDENT AID COMMISSION IS USED TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR A CAL GRANT AWARD. RECONCILIATION IS COMPLETED EVERY TERM AFTER PAYMENT TRANSACTIONS ARE REPORTED THROUGH WEBGRANTS ON A STUDENT-BY-STUDENT BASIS. THE DIRECTOR & ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS. INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT MEET THE SPECIFIC AWARD'S CRITERIA. THE INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED IN CAMS AND TRANSFERRED OVER TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS ONCE PAYMENT HAS BEEN MADE.

SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO MEET THE FINANCIAL REQUIREMENTS AS DEMONSTRATED BY THE RESULTS FROM FEDERAL FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ALSO MEET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA AS IDENTIFIED BY THE DONORS. INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID IS ALSO AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO MEET SPECIFIC MERIT OR AFFILIATION CRITERIA. RECIPIENTS OF TUITION REMISSION AND EXCHANGE PROGRAMS ARE VERIFIED FIRST BY THE DIRECTOR OF HUMAN RESOURCES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: DESCRIPTION FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, QUESTION 2 The College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College. Certain criteria are established that each student is required to meet to retain their scholarship. The College does not need to monitor the use of scholarship funds as those amounts are directly spent to defray the cost of tuition. There is no opportunity for the funds to be directed to another purpose.

THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS SEVERAL TYPES OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS UPON ADMISSION AND CREDITED AGAINST THEIR TUITION EACH QUARTER AS LONG AS GPA REQUIREMENTS ARE MET AND MAINTAINED. GPA IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE AND VERIFIED THROUGH THE STUDENT RECORDS PROGRAM. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE UPON ADMISSION BASED ON APPLICATION AND ESSAY SUBMISSION. THE SCHOLARSHIPS MAY BE ONE TIME OR RECUR EACH QUARTER, DEPENDING ON THE TYPE OF SCHOLARSHIP. THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT MONITORS APPLICATIONS AND AWARDS, AND THE FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE, IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE REGISTRAR, MONITORS QUARTERLY ELIGIBILITY OF RECURRING SCHOLARSHIPS. OTHER LIMITED ONE-TIME SCHOLARSHIPS MAY BE AWARDED AT THE DISCRETION OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT. THE CURRENT YEAR DISBURSEMENTS WERE FUNDED BY THE SCHOOL AS LENDER PROGRAM.

Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 - Procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds Martin University only awards institutional and privately funded financial aid awards as assistance for students based on a case by case basis, based on merit and need. In doing so, the University's financial aid department adheres strictly to all federal and state regulations and is subject to the internal control requirements of the OMB Circular A-133.
The University's financial aid department monitors and maintains records regarding all financial aid awards.

Students qualify for federal, state, and institutional scholarships, grants, and loans based on their individual FAFSA application. Merit awards are based on levels of achievement academically, musically, or artistically. Entitlement grants are given for students with a family connection to the College, denominational affiliation, and travel grants for students traveling a long distance from campus. International students may be awarded grants and scholarships to come to study. Grants are awarded by the financial aid office following federal, state and institutional guidelines, which are also monitored and applied in the business office. Funds are audited annually by independent auditors.

The college student financial aid office maintains records to substantiate the amounts of tuition assistance including eligibility criteria. This office ensures that funds are properly credited to student accounts and monitors students' continuing eligibility to receive financial assistance.

Our financial aid office awards scholarships to students based on submitted FAFSA data and academic performance. The financial aid office is responsible for ensuring compliance with all relevant state and federal requirements relative to grant-based aid.
Saybrook keeps detailed records for all student grants. Records include the need of the students and their progress toward a degree.

GRANTS GIVEN TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS ARE TO FURTHER EDUCATION, HEALTHCARE AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN THE AREAS SURROUNDING THE ORGANIZATION. ALL GRANTS ARE GIVEN TO ORGANIZATIONS WITH BOARDS CONSISTING OF CIVIC, PHILANTHROPIC AND BUSINESS LEADERS WHO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANTS AND ENSURE THEY'RE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES. SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TOWARDS THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED ONLY FOR STUDENT EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

For federal and state financial aid grants, individual FAFSA and personal tax returns are verified for recipient eligibility. Several layers of supervisory approvals are built into the internal financial aid process. For other federally funded grants (NIH, etc.), activity is administered by a dedicated employee, subject to several layers of supervisory review and approval. Payroll costs and other allocated expenditures are documented and reviewed by the Finance Dept. as well at external auditors.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THE RESULT OF TITLE IV AID, THEN THESE FUNDS ARE AUTOMATICALLY DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT WITHIN 14 DAYS. IF THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE THE RESULT OF SOMETHING OTHER THAN TITLE IV AID, THE STUDENT MUST REQUEST A REFUND AND THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

Scholarship amounts are applied directly to student accounts after a thorough review of eligibility and selection criteria. The university has an experienced financial aid department that monitors the use of grant funds.

Robert Morris University Illinois provides a number of grants/scholarship awards to eligible students based on various criteria such as financial need, merit, academic ability, academic major, and location of attendance. This gift assistance is supported by two important sources: the University reserves a portion of its budget for grants/scholarships, and financial support is contributed by faculty, staff, alumni and friends of the University.

INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN STUDENTS. DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR ARE SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE'S GOVERNING BOARD DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS FROM THE COLLEGE, IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS, ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.
THE ORGANIZATION ONLY GAVE NON-CASH TUITION REDUCTION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS SET CRITERIA FOR SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS.
All funds distributed to students are done so in accordance with the organization's established financial aid policies.

THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS BASED ON VARYING AWARD CRITERIA INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED AND ESSAYS. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS RANGE IN NATURE FROM SIBLING AND LEGACY SCHOLARSHIPS TO ATHLETIC AND PROGRAM SPECIFIC AWARDS. THE HARCUM GRANTS AND COMMUNITY BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE NEED BASED AND DETERMINED BY THE STUDENT'S EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION. ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO DISPLAY SUPERIOR ATHLETIC ABILITIES.

ALL STUDENT AID, GRANTS, WORK STUDY AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GIVEN ON BEHALF OF STUDENTS ATTENDING SITTING BULL COLLEGE. THE FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE TUITION, BOOKS, AND FEES FOR THE CORRESPONDING STUDENT TO ENSURE THAT IT IS USED FOR THE APPROPRIATE PURPOSES.
STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION SHOWING FINANCIAL NEED. THE STUDENTS MUST USE THE SCHOLARSHIP AT THE CINCINNATI COLLEGE OF MORTUARY SCIENCE AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Based on financial need.
GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED FOR APPROPRIATE USE BY VALIDATING REGISTRATION AND SATISFACTORY PROGRESS TOWARDS COMPLETION OF EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: ALL SCHOLARSHIP RECEIPIENTS ARE APPROVED BY THE BOARD

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Phoenix Seminary, Inc. students must submit applications for specific scholarships available each semester. Once the scholarship applications are submitted, the scholarship committee reviews and scores the applications based on the answers provided by the students. The scholarship committee then awards the scholarships based on the students meeting the scholarship criteria. Scholarships are disbursed based on the amount of funds available and the number of students meeting the scholarship criteria that apply.

The scholarship related records are maintained in the Financial Aid office. There is a scholarship committee established to formulate guidelines and procedures as to the eligibility and criteria for each scholarship being awarded. Additionally, records supporting non-scholarship type grants are also maintained between grant accounting and the Office of Grants and Sponsored Research.

STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE A FAFSA. ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS IS DETERMINED BY THE APPLICABLE FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES, BY THEIR ACADEMIC CREDENTIALS, AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS ARE APPROPRIATELY AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND THE AWARDS ARE TRANSFERRED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS IN THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT FUNDS ARE RECONCILED EACH SEMESTER AND REPORTED TO THE APPROPRIATE AUTHORITIES OR AGENCIES. FUNDS ARE ALSO AUDITED ANNUALLY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENT INSTITUTIONAL AID AND ASSISTANCE IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON MERIT AND/OR NEED AND IS APPLIED TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR REVIEWING EACH STUDENT'S CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND OTHER MERIT BASED CRITERIA ALONG WITH A COMPLETED APPLICATION FOR STUDENT FEDERAL AID AND DETERMINES WHETHER A NEED LEVEL IS SUBSTANTIATED BY THE APPLICATION. THE AID AND ASSISTANCE PAYS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD, AND BOOKSTORE CHARGES.

Defiance College awards financial aid on the basis of merit and on the basis of demonstrated need determined in conjunction with the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA). Defiance College scholarships are awarded to eligible students in varying amounts up to full tuition the first year and are renewed each year according to established renewal requirements. Defiance College awards are coordinated with federal, state, and other outside financial aid award programs.

THE ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IS DONE BY the FINANCIAL DEPARTMENT WHERE THEY KEEP REPORTS FROM GRANTS RECEIVED AND TO WHAT THEY ARE BEING GRANTED TO. The organization provides financial aid and scholarships directly to the recipient's student account, and the finance department keeps record of grants made.

THE PROCESS FOR MONITORING TUITION DISCOUNT OR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AT LEES-MCRAE IS DONE BY UTILIZING A MATRIX THAT DETERMINES AND LIMITS THE AMOUNT OF ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED. THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID MEET REGULARLY TO REVIEW THE MOST CURRENT AMOUNT OF AWARDS BEING AWARDED TO ENSURE THE COLLEGE STAYS WITHIN BUDGE AND AWARD GUIDELINES. A FINAL REVIEW IS DONE BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID PRIOR TO AWARD LETTERS BEING MAILED.

meredith college financial assistance office has systems and internal procedures in place that ensures the proper determination, disbursement and monitoring of grants and scholarships. these systems and procedures comply with the federal student title iv aid regulations, north carolina state education assistance authority rules, and institutional policies.

STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE DETERMINED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID THROUGH CAREFUL STUDY OF THE INFORMATION ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA), THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD, TEST SCORES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS. DETAILED RECORDS AND STATISTICS ARE MAINTAINED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND THE OFFICE OF ASSESSMENT AND INSTITUTIONAL RESEARCH IN REGARDS TO ALL FINANCIAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE, INCLUDING GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The College's procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds requires verification of 1) enrollment status, 2) number of hours enrolled, 3) number of earned credit hours, 4) GPA, and 5) housing status. In addition, a review of student academic performance and grades of incomplete, if applcable, is conducted each semester to determine overall standing in relation to College's established Satisfactory Academic Policy (SAP).
Funds are awarded to students eligible to receive financial aid in accordance with federal guidelines.
THE TRUST DOCUMENT SPECIFIES THAT CERTAIN FUNDS ARE TO BE DISTRIBUTED TO THE OTHER TRUSTS AND TO THE COLLEGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form Sch I Part I Line 2
ExplntnTxt: GRANT SUBSTANTIATION THE ORGANIZATION FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. FOR MERIT-BASED GRANTS, THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS THE GRANTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE STIPULATIONS OF THE UNDERLYING GOVERNING INSTRUMENT (I.E. DONOR ENDOWMENT AGREEMENTS, AND OTHER DONOR DOCUMENTATION). THE ORGANIZATION MAINTAINS DETAILED RECORDS OF COMPLIANCE FOR ALL GRANTS DISPERSED. ASSISTANCE TO MOREHOUSE COLLEGE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE PURPOSE OF AIDING WITH THE COST OF ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY, I.E. FOR TUITION, HOUSING, AND MEALS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, NEED, AND OTHER DONOR REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS LOCATION OF RESIDENCE. MOREHOUSE COLLEGE HAS CRITERIA FOR THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS NEEDED TO AWARD A SCHOLARSHIP.
The organization utilizes financial aid software and a monitoring system to ensure that aid is awarded properly according to university, state and federal guidelines.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE CLOSELY MONITORS ANY CHANGES IN THE STATUS OF FINANCIAL AWARD RECIPIENTS THAT WOULD RESULT IN A CORRESPONDING CHANGE IN THE AMOUNT OF AID AWARDED. ANY SUCH CHANGES ARE AUTOMATICALLY DETECTED AND REPORTED BY A SERIES OF SPECIAL REPORTS THAT ARE RUN ON A REGULAR BASIS. MOREOVER, THE OFFICE OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS ENSURES THAT THE CHARGES TO WHICH THE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE APPLIED ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE INTENDED USE OF THE AWARDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE US
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID FUNDS EACH YEAR BASED UPON A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED. ADDITIONALLY, THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES INSTITUTIONAL AID VIA UNIVERSITY GRANTS ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER STANDARDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS AND THE PERSONAL INCOME DATA PROVIDED FOR ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) OF EACH STUDENT TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF AID AWARDED ON AN AS NEEDED BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS FUNDED THROUGH SPECIAL ENDOWMENTS AND DONATIONS, WHICH ARE AWARDED BASED ON SIMILAR STANDARDS AS WELL AS DONOR'S CRITERIA. THE OFFICES OF FINANCIAL AID AND FINANCE CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENTS ADHERENCE TO ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS GPA AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.

ALAYA PRESCHOOL HAS CHILDREN WHO RECEIVE SOME SCHOLARSHIP SUPPORT IN THE FORM OF TUITION REDUCTION IN ADDITION TO OTHER CHILDREN THAT RECEIVE SUPPORT VIA CCCAP (COLORADO CHILD CARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM). THIS IS A STATE FUNDED PROGRAM FOR LOW INCOME FAMILIES. THE ORGANIZATION DOES NOT GET FULLY REIMBURSED FOR THE REGULAR COST OF CARE SO SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED TO FUND THE DIFFERENCE FOR THESE FAMILIES.

The organization has a Grants and Contracts management system for ensuring compliance with federal, state, local and private grant stipulations and requirements. Each program is responsible for monitoring the individual grants and contracts. The College retains independent auditors who prepare the federal OMB Circular A-133 audit for compliance.

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IN THE EVENT OF EARLY WITHDRAWAL, REFUNDS ARE GRANTED BASED ON THE FOLLOWING SCHEDULE: THE CHARGE FOR STUDENT MEDICAL INSURANCE IS NONREFUNDABLE. ROOM AND BOARD: THE ROOM AND BOARD WILL BE PRO-RATED ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER OF DAYS THE STUDENT WAS ON CAMPUS. TUITION AND FEES: IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS BEFORE THE FIRST DAY OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE REFUNDED, LESS AN ADMINISTRATIVE FEE OF ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS ($100.00). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS AFTER THE FIRST DAY OF CLASS BUT BEFORE THE END OF THE SECOND WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE CHARGED AT THE RATE OF TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT (25%). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS DURING THE THIRD OR FOURTH WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION WILL BE CHARGED AT THE RATE OF SEVENTY-FIVE PERCENT (75%). IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS AFTER THE FOURTH WEEK OF CLASS, FEES AND TUITION ARE DUE AND PAYABLE IN FULL. ALL REFUNDS WILL BE ISSUED WITHIN TEN BUSINESS DAYS OF A STUDENT'S OFFICIAL WITHDRAWAL DATE. REQUESTS FOR REFUNDS ARE REVIEWED BY THE BUSINESS MANAGER FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ESTABLISHED WITHDRAWAL PROCEDURES. THE EXCEPTION TO THIS IS FOR STUDENTS ELIGIBLE FOR VA BENEFITS. IN ORDER TO REMAIN IN COMPLIANCE WITH VA REGULATIONS, THE FOLLOWING REFUND POLICY APPLIES: VETERANS AND OTHER ELIGIBLE STUDENTS: CROWN COLLEGE OF THE BIBILE HAS A PRO-RATA REFUND POLICY FOR THE REFUND OF THE UNUSED PORTION OF TUITION, FEES AND OTHER CHARGES IN THE EVENT THE VETERAN OR ELIGIBLE PERSON FAILS TO ENTER THE COURSE OR WITHDRAWS OR IS DISCONTINUED THERE FROM AT ANY TIME PRIOR TO COMPLETION. CROWN COLLEGE DOES NOT PARTICIPATE IN THE TITLE IV STUDENT FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS OF THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION.

THE TRANSFERS TO THE COLLEGE FOR HCC RENOVATIONS, EQUIPMENT, AND THEATER TECHNOLOGY UPGRADES WERE FACILITATED AND MONITORED VIA PROCESSES BY DESIGNATED CPCC DEPARTMENT MANAGERS. DEPARTMENTAL EXPENSES FUNDED BY COLLEGE COURSEWARE ROYALTIES ARE REQUESTED BY THE DEPARTMENT HEADS FOR SPECIFIC USE AND ARE APPROVED BY MICHAEL MOSS (VP FINANCE), KEVIN MCCARTHY (VP INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT) AND QUINCY FOIL WHITE (AVP SERVICES CORP).

THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES AND INTERNAL NON-DISCRIMINATORY GUIDELINES FOR INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING. INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING IS BASED ON NEED, ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS AND INSTITUTIONAL PROGRAM NEEDS AND IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

THE MAJORITY OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE IN THE FORM OF FINANCIAL AID TO ITS STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS NEED AND MERIT BASE AID BASED ON THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE UNIVERSITY. THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM AT SETON HILL UNIVERSITY ASSISTS STUDENTS WHO WOULD FIND IT DIFFICULT OR IMPOSSIBLE TO ATTEND COLLEGE WITHOUT SOME FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS, PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT, AND DEFERRED PAYMENT SCHEDULES, AND COORDINATES ITS PROGRAMS WITH THE FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMS. ANY OF THESE FORMS OF FINANCIAL AID MAY BE OFFERED INDEPENDENTLY OR IN VARIOUS COMBINATIONS TO A STUDENT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ESTIMATES THE COST OF ATTENDING SETON HILL UNIVERSITY BY ADDING TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES PLUS AN ESTIMATE FOR BOOKS, SUPPLIES, TRANSPORTATION FROM HOME TO SCHOOL AND PERSONAL EXPENSES. THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID AN APPLICANT RECEIVES IS BASED ON THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE TOTAL COSTS AND THE AMOUNT THE STUDENT AND FAMILY ARE ABLE TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARD COSTS AS DETERMINED BY THE NEEDS ANALYSIS FORM.

ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVE GRANTS ARE PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS. THE UNIVERSITY'S STUDENTS GAIN PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE WHILE ASSISTING AT THESE ORGANIZATIONS. BECAUSE OF THIS CLOSE RELATIONSHIP, THE UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO MONITOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. THE UNIVERSITY APPLIES SCHOLARSHIPS DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' TUITION ACCOUNTS.

THE MAJORITY OF INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS IS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, FOR WHICH THE UNIVERSITY HAS A PREDETERMINED GRID THAT PROVIDES THE AMOUNTS TO BE AWARDED BASED ON THE STUDENTS ACTUAL GPA AND TEST SCORES AND AS NEEDED, EVALUATION BY THE UNIVERSITY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. OTHER INSTITUTIONAL AID CONSISTS OF RETURN MISSIONARY, TALENT AND OTHER NEED-BASED GRANTS. RETURNED MISSIONARY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,500 PER YEAR TO ALL FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED A MISSION FOR THE CHURCH OF JESUS CHRIST OF LATTER-DAY SAINTS. TALENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN VARIOUS AMOUNTS, TYPICALLY BETWEEN $500 AND $2,000 PER STUDENT, AND ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE NOMINATION OF THE UNIVERSITY FACULTY, ART/THEATRE/MUSIC DIRECTOR, ETC. AND APPROVAL OF THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE. UNIVERSITY GRANTS AND VARIOUS OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED AS DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR. FEDERAL & STATE GRANTS, INCLUDING PELL, SEOG, SMART, AND VTAG ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND MEET THE VARIOUS QUALIFICATIONS. FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS ARE VERIFIED INTERNALLY BY OUR FINANCIAL AID STAFF. THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (DOE) SELECTS A MINIMUM 30% OF ALL STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FAFSA TO VERIFY. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE APPROPRIATE VERIFICATION DOCUMENTATION TO THE DOE AND MAINTAINS A COPY OF THESE DOCUMENTS ON FILE.
THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES INSTITUITIONAL AID TO STUDENTS MAINTAINING ENROLLMENT.

GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND OTHER VARIOUS AREAS. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION, AND DISTRIBUTION. DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED AND AUDITED ANNUALLY. OTHER DEPARTMENT GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE DEPARTMENT CHAIR AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT EXPENDITURES COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND ARE NOT DIVERTED FOR OTHER USES.
FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BY FINANCIAL PROFESSIONAL IN ACCORDANCE WITH COLLEGE POLICIES.

All Oak Hills Christian College scholarships are monitored by the Financial Aid Office with attention given to the criteria set forth for each award as well as the student's enrollment status. The scholarships are applied directly to the student accounts. Camp scholarship assistance is available for campers whose families are financially unable to send their children to camp. The camper must be registered with a $25 deposit and submit a scholarship request form. The amount of scholarship requested will be applied to the camper's registration fee. A camper may request only one scholarship per calendar year. CIM(MMC) scholarships are awared based upon student need.

Scholarships and grants are distributed to students by posting the funds directly to their student accounts to offset charges for tuition, fees, and room and board. Any remaining credit is refunded to the student via check or direct deposit for use in purchasing books, housing, food, etc. Contributions to exempt organizations that further the University's exempt purpose require approval of a vice president.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: BETHANY COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS ON EVERY INDIVIDUAL WHO RECEIVES FUNDS. THESE RECORDS INCLUDE THE AMOUNT RECEIVED AND QUALIFICATIONS MET IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THOSE FUNDS. THEY ARE KEPT FOR THE DURATION OF TIME AS SPECIFIED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND ARE PROPERLY DISPOSED OF AFTWRWARDS. THE COLLEGE ALSO HAS A POLICIES AND PROCEDURES MANUAL WHICH STATES HOW SPECIFIC GRANT MONIES, SUCH AS THE KANSAS COMPREHENSIVE GRANT AND THE SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT, ARE AWARDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE FOUNDATION DOES NOT AWARD GRANTS BUT PROVIDES OTHER ASSITANCE IN THE FORM OF CONTRIBUTIONS AND NON-CASH CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE UNIVERSITY AND ITS EDUCATION FOUNDATION AS SUPPORT FOR THE UNIVERSTIY AS OUR 509(A)(3) STATUS REQUIRES.
Financial Aid monitors all the scholarships that are awarded to the students to make sure they fall within the required guidelines.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ESTABLISHED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS CAN BE INCREASED THROUGH CONTRIBUTIONS OR BY A BOARD RESOLUTION TO ADD A PORTION OF ANY SURPLUS IN A GIVEN YEAR TO A FUND.

The College maintains complete records for the grants and scholarships provided to all individuals. Those records indicate the criteria used to award the grants, documentation supporting the grantee's eligibility of the award, and substantiation of the amounts awarded. Documentation is also maintained as to when and how the funds are utilized. Where appropriate, periodic reports are prepared, summarizing the allocation of funds, and a reconciliation of the amounts spent for each grant and scholarship is completed. The College employs individuals whose primary responsibilities are to oversee the process of distributing financial grants and scholarships. The number of scholarship and grant recipients for the cost of attendance are tracked by the administrative system. The number of faculty and student recipients of research awards are estimated based on the type of grants awarded and the number of participants.
STUDENTS ARE VERIFIED FOR ELIGIBILITY AND FUNDS ARE POSTED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. ACCOUNT IS REFUNED IF NOT USED IN SPECIFIED TIME OR IF STUDENT WITHDRAWS.

Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment, the basis of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards. The University determines who qualifies for loans based on analysis by the Financial Aid Office. Loans are awarded as part of a package consisting of Federal Grants, Federal and University loans, Federal work-study and University scholarships. In all cases, those who receive loans have demonstrated financial need and have completed a Federal financial aid application form. The amounts received are added to the Student's account to offset the cost of tuition and fees.

THE COLLEGE HAS A NUMBER OF FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS. WITH THE ISSUANCE OF EACH AWARD A TEMPORARILY RESTRICTED ACCOUNT IS CREATED IN THE DATABASE. AWARD LETTERS ARE KEPT IN A SEPARATE FILE WITH THE PRIMARY CONTACT INFORMATION. IF THE GRANTEE DOES NOT HAVE ELIGIBILITY THE GRANT IS NOT AWARDED. IF THE ELIGIBILITY OF THE GRANTEE HAS CHANGED THE INSTITUTION RETURNS THE AWARDED FUNDS. THE GRANTS ARE BASED ON FAMILY INCOME CONTRIBUTIONS, AND/OR ACADEMIC STANDING, AND/OR ATHLETIC ABILITY, AND/OR INDIVIDUAL TALENT.

Midland University OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ADMINISTERS, RECONCILES, AND REPORTS ALL AID TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GRANT AGENCY PROCEDURES. FUNDS ARE VERIFIED, REVIEWED, AND RECONCILED TO ENSURE APPROPRIATE RECORDING.
Schedule I, Part I, Line 2--Grants are administered through the Office of Financial Aid for all federal, state and institutional aid program.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: For all scholarship funds, student financial services has established specific criteria in regards to eligibility and selection. The eligibility requirements of the students are documented and monitored for compliance. The actual scholarships are credited to the student's tuition bills. No scholarships or grants are awarded directly to the recipients.

OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON SUBMITTED FAFSA DATA AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING COMPLIANCE WITH ALL RELEVANT STATE AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS RELATIVE TO GRANT-BASED AID.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF MERIT AND NEED. FIRST YEAR STUDENTS MAY BE AWARDED SPECIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED AND MERIT AS DETERMINED BY THE APPLICANT'S APPLICATION AND AUDITION. SECOND YEAR AND ACADEMY COMPANY STUDENTS MAY APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS BY WRITING TO THE ACADEMY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHICH MAKES ALL SCHOLARSHIP DECISIONS. DETAILS ARE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANT POLICY IS CONTAINED IN ALL ADMISSIONS MATERIAL, IN THE UNIVERSITY CATALOG, AND CAN ALSO BE FOUND ON THE UNIVERSITY'S WEBSITE. THE UNIVERSITY USES A MATRIX MODEL TO AWARD MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AID AT THE TIME A STUDENT IS ADMITTED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE AMOUNT AWARDED IS BASED ON THE STUDENT'S HIGHEST SAT OR ACT SCORES AND WEIGHTED CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE. ADDITIONAL FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE DETERMINED IN CONJUNCTION WITH A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC AND THE FAMILY'S FINANCIAL INFORMATION TO DETERMINE THE EXACT SIZE AND COMPOSITION OF THE FINAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGES. THE TYPICAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE CONSISTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS, AND AN OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN A WORK STUDY PROGRAM WHICH SUPPLEMENTS EACH FAMILY'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE TOTAL COST OF EDUCATION. THE AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BASED UPON THE RESULTS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) CONTAINING INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE STUDENT AND PARENTS.
Grants awarded based on merit.

Financial aid is available to students who can show financial need, academic achievement, leadership/service, athletics ability, and/or talent. Academic and leadership awards are determined through the Admissions area, athletics awards are determined by the respective coach, talent/departmental awards are determined through those academic areas, and the Financial Aid Office coordinates all awards with federal, state and institutional need-based aid.
The University follows all government guidelines for awarding scholarships to students. Scholarships are made for academic merit and financial need.

REGIS UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF FUNDS BY ENSURING EXPENSES COMPLY WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND GUIDELINES INCLUDING, THE DEPT OF EDUCATION'S STUDENT FINANCIAL AID HANDBOOK AND THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION'S POLICY GUIDELINES AND AUDIT GUIDE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: MARYVILLE UNIVERSITY USES FINANCIAL AID COMPUTER SOFTWARE THAT PROVIDES ALL DETAILS OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS TO RECIPIENTS TO INCLUDE ANNUAL AND CUMULATIVE AMOUNTS AND ELIGIBILITY. ALL GRANTS IN AID ARE POSTED AS A CREDIT TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

GRANTS ARE PRIMARILY TO STUDENTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNT RECEIVABLE BALANCE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS PRIMARILY RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING THE ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF THE AID. THIS IS DONE THROUGH SOFTWARE DESIGNED TO ASSIST IN THE PROCESS.

WLC AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS MEETING CERTAIN FINANCIAL NEED TESTS AND ACADEMIC MERIT LEVELS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINE ARTS ABILITIES, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS SET BY THE BOARD OF REGENTS OR DONORS OF RESTRICTED OR ENDOWED FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY EXECUTES SUB-AWARD AGREEMENTS WITH THE GRANTEES THAT OUTLINE AWARD EXPECTATIONS. GRANTEES SUBMIT DETAILED INVOICES THAT ARE APPROVED FOR PAYMENT BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND THE OFFICE OF FISCAL AFFAIRS AND ADMINISTRATION. PAYMENT IS MADE ON A REIMBURSEMENT BASIS ONLY. GRANTEES ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT PROJECT REPORTS PERIODICALLY TO PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS. GRANTEES RECEIVING FEDERAL FUNDS AS SUBRECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE AN OMB CIRCULAR A-133 COMPLIANCE LETTER ANNUALLY, ALONG WITH A COPY OF AUDIT REPORTS.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON EITHER THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA OF THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING, ACADEMIC MERIT, OR TALENT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS SCHOLARSHIP FUND AVAILABILITY, MAKES SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS, AND MAINTAINS AN ON-GOING AWARENESS OF STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS.

To ensure our grants and scholarships are used for proper purpose the Financial Aid Office performs regular maintenance and reconciliation with our Bursar's Office monitoring that all funds awarded to a particular student are being properly credited to their student account. Any changes or adjustments to original awards that affect grant and scholarship funding are documented, saved and then copied to our Bursar's Office. These processes are completed utilizing an automated software system which allows us to generate reports at anytime for monitoring and reconciliation purposes. Additionally, we have a yearly audit performed by an outside accounting firm guaranteeing we are staying in compliance with all federal, state, and institutional policies and procedures as well as assuring funding is being used as intended.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The college receives grant funds from the U.S. Department of Education through the Title III and IV programs. The college awards federal financial aid to students based on eligibility criteria specified by federal regulations. The college has sophisticated internal processes to determine a student's eligibility for federal financial aid, and to monitor compliance.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND STUDENT ACCOUNTING AND IS CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY.
COLLEGE PARK ACADEMY DOES NOT REGULARLY AWARD GRANTS. THIS GRANT WAS TO ASSIST ITS RELATED ORGANIZATION, COLLEGE PARK PLUS, TO PAY OFF A LINE OF CREDIT BEFORE THE ORGANIZATION'S DISSOLUTION.

In 2013, Wongu University offered the "Founder's Class Scholarship" to all incoming students. After the student's first quarter, the Scholarship is continued based on specified performance standards including a minimum cumulative GPA. All students were informed of these standards. Students were also informed that the scholarship program would be continued until such time as the student receives the Masters Degree in Oriental Medicine. From 2014-2015, new students were offered a President's Award Scholarship for 4 quarters or until the University qualified to offer Title IV funds; whichever came first.

Although students and their families bear the primary responsibility for meeting costs, many find they cannot pay the full cost of an education by themselves. In most cases a financial aid package will involve family contributions, acceptance of federal assistance (including grants and loans), and financial aid from John Brown University. These financial assistance programs help fill the gap between the amount a family is expected to pay and the total educational cost. The amount the family is expected to pay is based on information provided on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA).
RECORDS VERIFYING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED YEARLY FOR EACH ORGANIZATIION

THE UNIVERSITY ISSUES GRANTS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS, WHICH ALLOWS STUDENTS TO FURTHER THEIR EDUCATION. GRANTED FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY BILLING ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, AND OTHER COSTS OF EDUCATION. IN FISCAL YEAR 2015-2016 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED DOMESTIC FINANCIAL AID TO SUPPORT 1283 STUDENTS
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING STERLING COLLEGE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE NON-CASH AWARDS, REQUIRING THE AWARDS TO BE USED AS A DIRECT REDUCTION IN TUITION COST.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants and scholarships are awarded to students via a direct reduction in their billed tuition for the term under which the grant or scholarship applies. The use of these grants and scholarships is limited in that monies can only be applied to tuition costs related to the specific RFUMS program a recipient is enrolled in.
The scholarships are awarded to Spertus students and are used to offset their tuition costs.

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS ANY EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS OVER THEIR CHARGES, THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE COLLEGE HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE COLLEGE'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE COLLEGE'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

Grants are awarded to students based on eligibility requirements which are determined on the basis of financial need academic ability and (or) special abilities. Need based financial aid is determined by using federal regulations. Students must also maintain satisfactory academic progress which is monitored at the end of each semester. All grants are applied to tuition and fee accounts.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The college provides scholarships to students matriculating at the University; these scholarships may only be used by students to defray the costs of tuition and/or room and board. Since the students may not exercise any discretion on how the funds are spent, the college is not required to monitor the grants (other than to ensure that the student is fulfilling the requirements for earning the scholarship).

IT IS THE POLICY OF GRACE BIBLE COLLEGE TO PROCESS ALL INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AWARDS THROUGH THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHICH CONSISTS OF THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR, VICE PRESIDENT FOR BUSINESS AND FINANCE, AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR COMMUNITY LIFE AND STUDENT SERVICE. THE COMMITTEE MAY ALSO CHOOSE TO OCCASIONALLY INCLUDE OTHER PERTINENT FACULTY OR STAFF.

THE VP OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION STAFF OVERSEE THAT THE PROVISIONS OF THE GRANT ARE MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUIDELINES OR AGREEMENTS SET FORTH, WHETHER THAT'S USE OF DONOR, GOVERNMENT OR PRIVATE SOURCES.
Financial aid assistance is awarded based on US Federal, State, and Private guidelines as required by the corresponding type of assistance.

The College's Financial Aid Office has a set of criteria by which College Aid is awarded to students. The Financial Aid Office maintains records of all student aid awarded and substantiation for the awards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, AND/OR ENROLLMENT STATUS. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS (SAP) IS THE MEANS USED TO MONITOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED. SAP MEASURES BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE PROGRESS. THE AWARDS ARE USED FOR TUITION, ROOM, AND BOARD.
ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED GRANTS IS DETERMINED BY THE SUBMISSION OF THE "FREE APPLICATION" FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY A STUDENT'S ADMISSION APPLICATION.

CORNELL MONITORS ALL GRANT RESOURCES THROUGH FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL AUDITS AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE, AND INTERNAL POLICY AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS PERIODIC AUDITING BY AND REPORTING TO THE FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AN INDEPENDENT AUDIT FIRM COMPLETES AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ALL GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE CORNELL'S MANAGEMENT TAKES THE NECESSARY STEPS TO INSURE CORNELL IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE MANY FEDERAL REGULATIONS RECIPIENTS OF GRANT AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE PRIMARILY FOR STUDENT AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY AND IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC AND ATHLETIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

COE COLLEGE RECEIVES VARIOUS FEDERAL GRANTS FROM NSF, DEPT OF EDUCATION AND OTHER AGENCIES OR BRANCHES OF THE US GOVERNMENT. SEPARATE ACCOUNTS ARE USED FOR EACH GRANT TO MONITOR RECEIPTS AND DISBURSEMENTS. THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS APPROPRIATE ACCOUNTING AND INTERNAL CONTROL PROCEDURES. ALL REQUIRED FINANCIAL REPORTING TO THE GRANT PROVIDER ARE COMPLETED TIMELY AND AUDITS BY AN INDEPENDENT CPA FIRM ARE DONE WHEN REQUIRED. THE COLLEGE ANNUALLY FILES AN A-133. DISTRIBUTIONS TO STUDENTS ARE MADE ACCORDING TO GRANT REQUIREMENTS.
THE SCHOOL APPLIES THE MONIES GRANTED TO STUDENTS FOR TUITION DIRECTLY TO TUITION COSTS.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY. THERE IS AN AWARD ELIGIBILITY CALCULATOR ON THE HEIDELBERG WEBSITE TO SEE IF YOU QUALIFY.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND MONITORS GRANTING OF AWARDS TO STUDENTS AND FOLLOWS U.S. FEDERAL AID REGULATIONS AND ALL STATES' REGULATIONS FOR GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS.

GRANTS AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITIES' POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

Scholarships & Grants are provided based the College's assessment of the recipients academic achievement, financial need, and other standards established by the college. Applications are reviewed and approved by the financial aid department.

HANOVER COLLEGE ONLY AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATELY FUNDED FINANCIAL AID AWARDS AS ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENTS BASED ON A CASE-BY-CASE BASIS, BASED ON MERIT, NEED AND EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. IN DOING SO THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROL REQUIREMENTS OF 0MB-A133, IN WHICH THEY FOLLOW ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES.

THE COLLEGE'S ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF OVERSEE THAT THE PROVISIONS OF THE GRANTS ARE MET IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GUIDELINES OR AGREEMENT SET FORTH, WHETHER THAT IS USE OF DONOR, GOVERNMENT OR INSTITUTIONAL SOURCES.

SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS THROUGH FINANCIAL AID, BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND FEDERAL OR STATE MANDATED REGULATIONS. DONOR RESTRICTED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ALSO MONITORED AND DISTRIBUTED THROUGH FINANCIAL AID PROCESSES TO COVER EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES ESTIMATED OR CHARGED BY THE UNIVERSITY.

Grants and aid are tracked in the accounting system in a temporarily restricted fund or reimbursed according to a qualified reimbursement policy. An audit of funds granted is conducted when deemed necessary. Funds are given and monitored by the mission trip teams that are sent to work with Del Camino each year. The funds are specifically used for the work done during the mission trip.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON STUDENT FINANCIAL NEED AND ABILITY. BOTH ARE BASED ON SET CRITERIA. THE CRITERIA FOR NEED BASED GRANTS IS BASED ON FEDERAL NEED LEVELS SUCH AS PELL ELIGIBILITY. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE STRENGTH OF THE STUDENT'S PORTFOLIO.

THE ACADEMIC PROGRESS OF FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS IS MONITORED A MINIMUM OF ONCE EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENTS SHOULD CONTACT THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH QUESTIONS REGARDING THE INTENT AND/OR INTERPRETATION OF THESE STANDARDS. COMPLETION RATE AND GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) REQUIREMENTS FULL-TIME STUDENTS (STUDENTS ATTEMPTING 12 OR MORE CREDIT HOURS EACH SEMESTER) MUST PROGRESS ACCORDING TO THE FOLLOWING SCHEDULE: MINIMUM CREDITS MINIMUM REQUIRED SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED CUMULATIVE GPA YEAR 1 24 1.70 YEAR 2 48 2.00 YEAR 3 72 2.00 YEAR 4 96 2.00 YEAR 5 123 2.00 THESE CREDIT HOURS MUST BE EARNED DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR (FALL, WINTER AND SPRING). HOWEVER, IF A STUDENT DOES NOT MEET THESE REQUIRED HOURS, THEY MAY BE EARNED DURING THE FOLLOWING SUMMER SESSION(S). FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD BY THE END OF THE SUMMER WILL RESULT IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE COMPLETED CUMULATIVE HOURS MEET THE MINIMUM STANDARDS. LOSS OF AID IS NOT THE SAME AS ACADEMIC SUSPENSION, WHICH IS HANDLED BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS. PART-TIME STUDENTS MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE ONE-HALF OF THE CREDIT HOURS THEY ATTEMPT. COMBINED STUDENTS (STUDENTS BLENDING TERMS OF FULL- AND PART-TIME ENROLLMENT) MUST ACHIEVE A CUMULATIVE TOTAL THAT SATISFIES THE COMBINED FULL- AND PART-TIME STANDARDS. STUDENTS WHO DO NOT ACHIEVE THE MINIMUM CUMULATIVE GPA ARE GRANTED ONE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER IN WHICH TO RAISE THEIR CUMULATIVE GPA TO THE MINIMUM. FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD AT ANY POINT FOLLOWING THE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER RESULTS IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE CUMULATIVE GPA MEETS THE MINIMUM STANDARDS.

THE SCHOOL HAS FELLOWSHIP RECIPIENTS SIGN THE AWARD LETTER TO ACCEPT CONDITIONS OF THE FELLOWSHIP, INCLUDING THE CONDITION THAT RECIPIENTS PARTICIPATE IN AN EXIT INTERVIEW WITH THE SCHOOL'S STAFF WITHIN SIX MONTHS AFTER CARRYING OUT THEIR FELLOWSHIP SERVICE.

ALL STUDENT AWARDS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE SYSTEM. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE BASED ON FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA PROVIDED BY THE STUDENT AND VERIFIED, AS APPROPRIATE, BY THE COLLEGE. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL AUDIT BASED ON STANDARDS FOUND IN THE UNIFORM GUIDANCE AND PERFORMED BY AN INDEPENDENT AUDITOR. SELECTION CRITERIA FOR DONOR-FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MOSTLY DETERMINED BY THE DONOR AND IS AVAILABLE IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. SELECTION CRITERIA FOR FEDERAL AND STATE AID IS ALSO FOUND IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ON THE INTERNET.

ALL INSTITUTIONAL MONEY, GRANTS, ETC. FOLLOW THE FINANCIAL AID MATRIX THAT WAS DESIGNED AND APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT'S CABINET, OR IF MONEY WAS DONATED FOR SPECIFIC PURPOSES, BY THE WISHES OF THE INDIVIDUAL DONOR.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING MCPHERSON COLLEGE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE NON-CASH AWARDS, REQUIRING THE AWARDS TO BE USED AS A DIRECT REDUCTION IN TUITION COST.
MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ONLY TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

Concordia University Inc. awards scholarships and financial aid to students based on financial need, talent, and/or academic merit and programs. Federal and State programs are awarded based upon respective program requirements. Federal and State programs are compliance tested yearly in conjunction with the independent audit and auditor reports/ newsletters are submitted to all organizations as required by the programs.

the College's procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds requires the verification of 1) enrollment status, 2) number of hours enrolled, 3) number of earned credit hours, 4) GPA, and 5) housing status. In addition, a review of student academic performance is conducted each semester to determine overall standing in relation to the college's established satisfactory academic policy (SAP).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE TUITION ASSISTANCE IS GIVEN TO THE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF A CREDIT TO THEIR ACCOUNT. THE TUITION ASSISTANCE IS NOT PERMITTED TO EXCEED THE STUDENT'S TUITION BILL.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY PRIMARILY CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED and monitored BY THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED UPON A NUMBER OF DIFFERENT CRITERIA, INCLUDING MERIT, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND FINANCIAL NEED. 1,583 students received financial aid during the current fiscal year from a combination of all Sources (Federal, state and institutional). Of the 1,583 students receiving financial aid, 1,583 received funding from institutional sources.
Need based scholarship funds to students

Need based financial aid comprises the larger part of the grants described in Part III, these grants are awarded for a maximum of eight semesters upon annual reapplication, subject to satisfactory academic and social standing. Merit based aid comprises the remainder of grants and assistance and requires maintenance of a minimum grade point average of 3.0
GETTYSBURG COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE DESCRIBED ON SCHEDULE F, PART V.

Students must submit their FAFSA Federal Form to document their need for federal financial aid. Once the financial aid is awarded, the grants are transmitted to the students' institutional accounts to pay for tuition charges, there is also a follow up process during the semester and school year to ensure academic credits completion and satisfactory academic progress before additional financial aid is awarded.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS MERIT-BASED SCHOLARHSIPS TO INCOMING FRESHMAN AS WELL AS CONTINUING STUDENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO FRESHMAN ARE DETERMINED BY THE ADMISSIONS COMMITTEE. ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE SCHOLARSHIPS IS DETERMINED THROUGH A COMBINATION OF THEIR UNDERGRADUATE CUMULATIVE SCIENCE GPA, RANKING OF THE COLLEGE ATTENDED, AND THE SCORE ACHIEVED ON THE MCAT, A STANDARDIZED MEDICAL SCHOOL ADMISSIONS TEST. FOR CONTINUING STUDENTS, THE TOP FIVE STUDENTS WITH A CUMULATIVE GPA OF 3.7 OR HIGHER FOR EACH GRADE, 2ND, 3RD, AND 4TH YEAR STUDENTS, RECEIVE THESE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE USE OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THOSE AMOUNTS ARE DIRECTLY SPENT TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION. THERE IS NO OPPORTUNITY FOR THE FUNDS TO BE DIRECTED FOR ANOTHER PURPOSE.

The financial aid office determines student eligibility for federal, state and institutional scholarships according to the University's established criteria which follows federal and state guidelines for awarding any grant funds. There is an annual audit to ensure compliance with these regulations.
This is internally funded assistance financed by the earnings of our restricted endowment fund as well as various outside scholarship gifts.

ALL SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA AS SET BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID POLICIES. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE POSTED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO BE APPLIED AGAINST CHARGES FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM, AND BOARD.
ORGANIZATION RECEIVES OFFICIAL RECEIPTS FOR THE GRANTS GIVEN
The College maintains records for all students receiving financial assistance administered by the College. Records include financial and academic performance records relative to award decisions.

STUDENTS INTERESTED IN A SCHOLARSHIP MUST APPLY THROUGH A WRITTEN APPLICATION PROCESS. ALL APPLICATIONS ARE THEN REVIEWED BY A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE THAT AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS ACCORDING TO WHETHER OR NOT THE APPLICANT MEETS THE CRITERIA FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP (FOR EXAMPLE, IF THE ENDOWMENT SCHOLARSHIP SPECIFIES THAT RECIPIENTS MUST BE FROM INNER-CITY DETROIT, ONLY THOSE WHO ARE SO ARE CONSIDERED) AND THEN BASED ON NEED VERSUS AVAILABLE FUNDS.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION DISCOUNTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND MISSION COMPATIBILITY OF THE STUDENT.
THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS THE GUIDELINES FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION

The financial aid office at Charleston Southern University requires students to complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for Federal, State and institutional grants, scholarships and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the institution does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based upon certain academic credentials or performance in a University sponsored activity or athletic event. These credentials are clearly stated in the University catalog and the University website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitored by the University.
The University makes occasional donations to charitable organizations which are not monitored beyond the original grant determination process.
The college manages Federal Title IV grant funds in accordance with Title IV regulations. The college undergoes an annual A-133 audit to monitor the use of the funds.

Monitoring the use of grant funds Y The assistance provided to governmental entities is in the form of donations in-lieu of real estate taxes. The amounts are intended to help fund services normally provided by the entities.

GRANT FUNDING IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS THROUGH THE ADMISSION PROCESS AS WELL AS THROUGH THE COMPLETION OF THE ANNUAL FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). UPON ACCEPTANCE TO THE UNIVERSITY, IF DETERMINED ELIGIBLE BY ADMISSIONS, TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS ARE AWARDED WITH INSTITUTIONAL MERIT OR PARTNERSHIP AID. WHEN THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL PLANNING (SFP) PACKAGES STUDENT AID, THESE FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO THE ELIGIBLE STUDENT. ONCE THE STUDENT HAS FILED THE FAFSA FORM, ADDITIONAL AID INCLUDING FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT/LOAN FUNDS ARE AWARDED AS WELL. AS FINANCIAL AID FILES ARE COMPLETED WITH MISSING DOCUMENTATION, STUDENT AID AWARDS ARE REVIEWED AND REVISED AS NECESSARY. THE SFP OFFICE WORKS CLOSELY WITH THE STUDENT ACCOUNT OFFICE (SAO) TO RECONCILE INSTITUTIONAL, FEDERAL AND GRANT FUNDING ON AN ONGOING BASIS THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR. REPORTS ARE RUN FROM THE SFP OFFICE AND SENT TO SAO TO REVIEW AND IDENTIFY ANY AID DISCREPANCIES. IF ANY ARE IDENTIFIED, THE AID IS ADJUSTED AS NECESSARY. THE SFP OFFICE REQUESTS A YEAR TO DATE FEDERAL PELL GRANT FILE FROM COD EVERY COUPLE OF MONTHS TO RECONCILE THE AWARDING, DISBURSEMENT AND CANCELLATION OF A STUDENT'S GRANT AWARDS. AS THE END OF THE AWARD YEAR COMES TO AN END REPORTS MAY BE RUN ON A WEEKLY BASIS FROM THE SFP, SAO AND COD SYSTEMS TO BE SURE ALL THE FUNDING AWARDED IS RECONCILED ACCURATELY.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ITS STUDENTS WITH SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. EACH STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY IS VERIFIED PRIOR TO AWARDING A SCHOLARSHIP. THE UNIVERSITY POSTS THE GRANT DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENT'S OUTSTANDING ACCOUNT BALANCE TO ENSURE THE PROPER USE OF AWARDED FUNDS.

FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED CONSISTENT WITH FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. FEDERAL PROGRAMS ARE SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDIT. THE SCHOOL'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH TYPE OF AWARD. VARIOUS CRITERIA MAY INCLUDE BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED OR OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE FUNDING SOURCE.

GRANT PROPOSALS ARE REVIEWED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTMAKING COMMITTEE. IF THE PROPOSAL MEETS THE GRANT GUIDELINES THE COMMITTEE DECIDES ON WHETHER TO FUND THE PROJECT. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS BASED ON DIFFERENT CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL POLICIES AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS WHEN IT AWARDS FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS TO SUBMIT REPORTS TO SUPPORT THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The Financial Aid Office and Business Office operate together to ensure grants are used for educational purposes. Grants are applied to students' accounts by the Business Office after the grants are approved and disbursed by the Financial Aid Office.
THE SCHOLARSHIPS/FINANCIAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS IS APPLIED AGAINST THEIR TUITION ACCOUNTS.

THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DETERMINES THE ELIGIBILITY OF ALL STUDENTS AT THE COLLEGE AND MAINTAINS APPROPRIATE RECORDS TO SUPPORT ELIGIBILITY. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT PACKAGES AID BASED ON INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S NEED. ALL STUDENT FINANCIAL AID CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS IS ELECTRONICALLY REPORTED TO THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION.

Scholarships/grants to students are determined by the Student Financial Services office. Each student file is reviewed in accordance with the designated eligibility requirements of the scholarships or grants. They are then monitored by disbursing funds from the SFS office into the respective student accounts.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S. AU PARTNERS WITH OTHER UNIVERSITIES AS NECESSARY TO PERFORM THE SCOPE OF THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE GRANTS AGREEMENTS. PRIOR TO ENGAGING WITH THESE SUB-AWARDEES, AU PERFORMS A RISK ASSESSMENT INCLUDING A REVIEW OF THE MOST RECENT FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AS WELL AS ENSURING THEY ARE NOT LISTED AS A DEBARRED ENTITY WITH ANY FEDERAL AGENCY. AU WORKS TO MONITOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS EXPENDED USING ITS PROCESSES AND CONTROLS INHERENT IN AU'S SYSTEM. BEFORE SELECTING THE RECIPIENT AND PERIODICALLY AS REQUIRED DURING THE GRANT OR SCHOLARSHIP TERM, AU IMPOSES ITS INSTITUTIONAL CRITERIA AND THE DONOR'S (WHEN APPLICABLE) TO MAKE SURE THAT THE FUNDS ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSES. THIS MONITORING IS DONE THROUGH A COLLABORATION OF VARIOUS DEPARTMENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY. PERIODIC SPENDING REPORTS ARE PULLED TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL OVERSIGHT OF SCHOLARSHIPS AS NECESSARY TO REPORT BACK TO DONORS ON THE STATUS OF THEIR GIFTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part III, Line 1 All students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the university's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and similar standards. Approximately 75% of full time freshmen applied for need based financial aid.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS WITHIN ITS FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE TO ACCOUNT FOR ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.

Student financial aid is awarded after an application and eligibility verification process, using the FAFSA for establishing financial need, and GPA and recommendations to establish merit. Competitions and other award qualifications are used to determine eligibility where applicable. Records are maintained in our Financial Aid office; scholarships and awards are applied directly to student accounts.

ALL UNIVERSITY STUDENTS ARE CONSIDERED FOR GRANTS AND/OR ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE EVALUATES EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED BASED UPON INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MANAGEMENT AWARD MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO QUALIFY BASED UPON DONOR STIPULATIONS AND AWARD FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE NEED-BASED AWARDS BASED ON FEDERAL OR OTHER GUIDELINES. STUDENTS RECEIVING AWARDS PROVIDE INFORMATION AND PARTICIPATE IN INTERVIEWS TO ENSURE THAT GUIDELINES AND RESIDENCY RULES AND REGULATIONS ARE MET.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students based on the scholarship criteria. For example, a student may need to be an accounting major, with a GPA of 2.0 or higher. Students complete a scholarship application and the applications are given to a scholarship committee for review. The scholarship committee verifies the student meets the scholarship criteria and then determines the distribution.

Concordia College offers scholarships and grants to qualified students to help reduce their out-of-pocket tuition costs. Students receiving financial assistance of this form must meet specific criteria such as academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards whether put in place by the college or by donors of restricted funds.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for monitoring use of grant funds inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Contributions made to other charitable organizations are made pursuant to University policy. Contributions by the University are made where they further the University's mission or its role as a good community citizen. All grants, including sub-grants, are accounted for separately by the University's financial accounting system and each is managed by a principal investigator. Financial activity reports are provided to principal investigators on a daily basis, with reconciliation of financial reports required on a monthly basis. Sub-grants are further monitored by obtaining a grantee's A-133 audits and evaluating the grantee's ability to comply with the terms of the sub-grant. All grant monitoring is subject to the policies and procedures of the University, which are designed to meet federal requirements. The University's Office of Institutional Compliance, Office of Research Services, Restricted Accounting and others are charged with ensuring that all DePaul employees are aware of their responsibilities in developing and maintaining a compliance-conscious environment. Additionally, the Office of Institutional Compliance, Office of Research Services, Restricted Accounting, Principal Investigators and others are charged with ensuring that the University's policies and procedures, as well as local, state and federal laws are followed. This is accomplished through conducting risk assessments, monitoring operational activities, providing online, classroom and/or one-on-one training and other tools that foster compliance. Grants and assistance to students represents financial assistance in the form of institutional scholarships. All scholarships are administered through the University's financial aid system. Institutional scholarships are credited to the student's internal account and represent an offset to tuition and other fees assessed by the University. Grants and assistance to University staff and their eligible spouse, dependents, or an unrelated second domiciled adult represent staff tuition waivers, pursuant to a written benefits plan. Staff tuition waivers are administered through the University's benefits system and, like institutional scholarships for students, are credited to the individual's internal account to offset tuition charges. Taxability of tuition waivers is determined pursuant to sections 127 and 117(d) of the Internal Revenue Code.
The Puritan Reformed Theological Seminary Foundation exists to support the Seminary. The Foundation manages the long term investments to provide operational and scholarship funds for the school.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Grant funds disbursed by the College are predominantly available as merit or need based scholarships. These scholarships are disbursed by the Financial Aid office and are credited directly to the student's account to pay for tuition, room and board. They are then monitored by the Financial Aid Office and the Student Accounts Office, both of whom are notified if the student's enrollment status changes during the semester. These offices monitor whether the grantee is taking the necessary classes and is therefore utilizing the grant as it was intended. If a student's enrollment changes, award adjustments are made. Other grant funds are disbursed by the College through Accounts Payable. Qualification and use of these payments are monitored by the respective departments responsible for the disbursement.

STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN HONOR SCHOLARSHIP MUST BE PART OF THE UNIVERSITY'S HONOR PROGRAM AND THIS PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS THAT THE STUDENTS MUST MEET EVERY TRIMESTER IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIP MUST MEET CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED BY THE ATHLETIC DEPARTMENT. STUDENTS ARE SELECTED BY A COMMITTEE PART OF THE VICE PRESIDENCY OF STUDENTS AFFAIRS.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDING AID, CHAPMAN UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFORNIA AID PROGRAMS. FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT WWW.CHAPMAN.EDU.

SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM, AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS FOR EACH STUDENT.
The College reconciles grants awarded and drawdowns of funds. Grant programs are audited by independent auditors during the annual independent audit.
THE COLLEGE PROVIDES ONGOING OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING TO ASSURE THE ACHIEVEMENT OF THE INTENDED PURPOSES AND TIMELY EXPENDITURES OF GRANT FUNDS.

Stipends and research fellowships are funds paid to offset living expenses for trainees while they further their education at Rockefeller. These amounts are not considered salary or wages given in consideration for specific job duties nor are they grants given in anticipation of specific scientific achievements on the individuals parts. There is no restriction on the use of the funds once they are received by the trainees.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE GRANTS ARE SUBJECT TO FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS A MONITORING POLICY FOR THE GRANTS, WHEN THEY ARE AWARDED A BUDGET IS APPROVED ESTABLISHING THE ALLOWABLE EXPENSES UNDER THE GRANT. IN THE CASE OF FUNDS PAID TO ANOTHER PERSON OR ENTITY THROUGH SUBCONTRACTING, PMSF HAS A WRITTEN POLICY ESTABLISHING REPORTING AND MONITORING GUIDELINES TO OVERSEE SUBCONTRACT. ONE OF THE REQUIREMENTS IS THAT SUB-RECIPIENTS HAVE PERFORMED AN INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133. SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE PMSF A DOCUMENT INDICATING THAT THEY MEET THE ESTABLISHED REQUIREMENTS AND PROVIDE A COPY OF THE A133 REPORT.PMSF ALSO PERFORMS SITE VISITS AND REQUIRES THE SUB-RECIPIENT TO SUBMIT PROGRESS. PMSF HAS A COMPLIANCE OFFICE THAT APPROVES EVERY DISBURSEMENT AFTER VERIFYING THAT IT MEETS FEDERAL REGULATIONS. DISBURSEMENTS APPROVED BY THE COMPLIANCE OFFICE ARE THEN SUBMITTED TO THE BUDGET DEPARTMENT FOR APPROVAL OF THE DISBURSEMENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE BUDGET APPROVED BY THE GRANTING AGENCY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: JD Admission Scholarships:Admission scholarships are granted based on merit. This includes, but is not always limited to: LSAT score and undergraduate grade point average. Some scholarships are also awarded based on merit and diversity. There is no separate application beyond the admissions application required for most of the scholarships. Merit Based Scholarships:California Western School of Law (the School) offers two forms of merit based scholarships that are awarded to students at the completion of their first year of law school. The Academic Merit Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 3.33 to 4.33. It is awarded based solely on the student's GPA. The Dean's Diversity Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 2.80 to 4.33. It is awarded through a competitive application process. The number of scholarships offered each year varies, based on the number of eligible students and the availability of funds.LL.M./M.C.L. Scholarships:These scholarships are awarded to the School's most academically outstanding LL.M./M.C.L. applicants based upon academic credentials, relevant work experience, impressive academic and professional recommendations, and strong command of English (as evidenced by quality writing on the applicant's personal statement and by the applicant's "Test of English as a Foreign Language"("TOEFL") score).Students enrolled in the School's Spanish on-line LL.M. program may apply for a scholarship if they can demonstrate long term commitment to trial advocacy, education, and justice system reforms. In addition, students in this program may also receive a small scholarship if they graduated from a school in Mexico that has a cooperation agreement (a "convenio") with the School.

Each student is reviewed by two or three individuals in the awarding process. Students are then awarded grant funds based on federal, state, and institutional regulations, guidelines and institutional matrix procedures for monitoring funds are also built into the computer awarding software.
Grants are given in the form of tuition scholarships to current students.

CCA MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT COMPLETE ADMISSION APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND PORTFOLIO REVIEW. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. RECIPIENTS OF NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND SEOG FUNDS MUST COMPLETE A FAFSA APPLICATION, BE US CITIZENS OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS, AND BE ENROLLED FULL-TIME.

Students requesting financial aid are screened for financial need, academic merit, and other scholarship criteria prior to the awarding of scholarships. The combined total of scholarships, grants and other tuition related awards may not exceed the cost of tuition. Students must meet the enrollment guidelines and maintain satisfactory academic progress to retain awards received. Monitoring of these criteria is a combined effort of the Financial Aid office, the Registrar's office and the Business office.
We follow the requirements of the research agreements.
