APPLICANTS MUST BE REGISTERED FOR A MINIMUM OF EIGHT CREDITS PER SEMESTER. A CREDIT FOR THE AWARDED AMOUNT IS APPLIED TO THE RECIPIENT'S ACCOUNT, NO ACTUAL CASH IS AWARDED DIRECTLY TO RECIPIENTS.

Subrecipient grants - Vanderbilt University maintains a formal policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Vanderbilt. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. The policy addresses the roles and responsibilities of central offices and academic departments of the University and describes the monitoring procedures for each area. The full text of Vanderbilt's subrecipient policy is available online at the following web address: http://www.vanderbilt.edu/ocga/vupolicies/subrecipient /SubrecipientMonitoringGuidelinesfinal.pdf Other Assistance - Assistance offered from institutional funds by Vanderbilt to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. Such assistance helps students and their families support the cost of attendance which includes tuition, mandatory fees, room & board, books, other course materials/supplies, and allowances for personal/miscellaneous and travel expenses. Merit-based awards are competitively awarded in recognition of academic achievement, leadership, commitment to community service, contributions to society, and other forms of accomplishment. Need-based assistance is awarded on the basis of documented financial need, resulting from a need analysis evaluation accomplished in accordance with relevant and applicable federal, state, and/or institutional programs, policies, and eligibility requirements. Financial Aid - The units responsible for administering student financial aid at Vanderbilt regularly initiate system-generated reviews, as well as other cross-checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews, along with recurring management reports, are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal University policies and operational guidelines/criteria.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Parts II and III, General
ExplntnTxt: In addition to the amounts reported on Core Form Part IX, Schedule I includes all relevant pre-Transaction VUMC amounts. For additional information, see the Core Form Part III, Line 3 disclosure in Schedule O.

CMU DISTRIBUTES LIMITED FINANCIAL AID AND GRANT FUNDS TO INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S. BASED ON A STATISTICAL MODEL THAT TAKES INTO ACCOUNT A STUDENT'S INTENDED COLLEGE MAJOR, ACADEMIC AND ARTISTIC TALENTS, NON-ACADEMIC TALENTS AND ABILITIES, AS WELL AS FINANCIAL NEED. FOR STUDENTS, SUCH FUNDS ARE TYPICALLY APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AT CMU. OTHER TYPES OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE MIGHT INCLUDE, FOR EXAMPLE, RECIPIENTS OF PRIZES AND AWARDS WHO HAVE MET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA FOR THE PARTICULAR PRIZE OR AWARD TO BE SELECTED. IN THE CASE OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, THE RECIPIENT IS OFTEN REQUIRED TO UTILIZE THE FUNDS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AND RESEARCH AT CMU. GRANTS ARE ALSO MADE IN THE CONTEXT OF ACADEMIC OR RESEARCH PROGRAMS AND RECIPIENTS SPEND THEIR GRANT FUNDS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PROGRAM FOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. SPONSORED PROJECT FUNDS ARE PASSED THROUGH TO SUB-GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS BY CARNEGIE MELLON WHEN SUCH SUB-GRANTEE ARRANGEMENTS ARE APPROVED BY THE PRIMARY GRANT SPONSOR. FUNDS ARE SPENT UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND ARE ACCOUNTABLE TO FEDERAL AND SPONSOR TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

WE BELIEVE THAT IN ORDER TO MAXIMIZE THE QUALITY OF THE LEARNING EXPERIENCE IT IS IMPORTANT TO CREATE A DIVERSE STUDENT BODY. LIKEWISE, AN EFFECTIVE LEGAL PROFESSION MUST REFLECT THE DIVERSITY OF MODERN SOCIETY. TO THAT END, OUR SCHOLARSHIP POLICY TAKES INTO ACCOUNT MANY FACTORS, INCLUDING MERIT (AS DEMONSTRATED BY LSAT SCORES AND UNDERGRADUATE GPA), SOCIO-ECONOMIC BACKGROUND, CULTURE, RACE, CAREER PLANS UPON GRADUATION, AND OTHER FACTORS SUGGESTING THAT A STUDENT WILL BOTH BENEFIT HIS OR HER FELLOW STUDENTS AND THE LEGAL PROFESSION. STUDENT GRADES ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED. COLLEGE FUNDED INSTITUTIONAL AND ENDOWED GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC MERIT. THE COLLEGE MONITORS THESE GRANTS AND AWARDS BY SEMESTER TO VERIFY THAT RECIPIENTS ARE MAINTAINinG THE MINIMUM STANDARDS REQUIRED TO RECEIVE THE GRANT OR AWARD.

The College determines the eligibility for each student's needs, the awards are credited to the student's account and the Office of Financial Aid monitors the student's continued eligibility to receive the assistance.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY ESTIMATES THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS FROM RECORDS MAINTAINED IN OUR FINANCIAL AID (SCHOLARSHIPS) AND ACCOUNTS PAYABLE SYSTEM (GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANCE STIPENDS AND FELLOWSHIPS) WHICH HAVE BEEN CLASSIFIED BY THE TYPE OF ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND OTHER STUDENT RELATED FINANCIAL AID MUST BE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH AN AUTOMATED SYSTEM AUTHORIZED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED EACH YEAR BY FINANCIAL AID IN CONJUNCTION/CONSULTATION WITH THE ADVANCEMENT DEPARTMENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Awards to undergraduates are based primarily on financial need determined by documented financial aid eligibility. Institutional need and merit awards, government grants and outside scholarships provided aid to 4,825 students during the year. Graduate students are admitted based on merit as determined by the department to which they are admitted for study and they receive aid from that department or from external agencies. Loans are awarded to eligible students based on need. Over $20 million was paid directly to students (Form 990, Part III, line 4a) with the remainder applied internally to tuition, fees, and room and board.
THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA. THE NUMBER OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED IN PART III, COLUMN(B) IS ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED DURING THE YEAR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN U.S.
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITuTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. The college does not further monitor the usage of scholarship funds as these amounts are credited directly against students tuition account and there is no opportunity for the student to divert these funds to non-educational uses.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 MIDWESTERN UNIVERSITY AWARDS ITS INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND COMMUNITY SERVICE. EACH SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM HAS DIFFERENT ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS, APPLICATION DEADLINES AND SEPARATE APPLICATION PROCEDURES. APPLICATIONS FOR THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ACCEPTED THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS CAN RANGE FROM A FEW HUNDRED DOLLARS TO SEVERAL THOUSAND DOLLARS. ONCE THE SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENT HAS BEEN SELECTED AND THE SCHOLARSHIP AWARD DETERMINED, THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES IS NOTIFIED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE OR DEPARTMENT. THE SCHOLARSHIP AWARD IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE UNIVERSITY HAS WRITTEN POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AND MAINTAINS RECORDS FOR GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ITS STUDENTS. Form 990, Schedule I, Part III, Line 3 Student Loan Forgiveness MIDWESTERN UNIVERSITY FROM TIME TO TIME FORGIVES THE LOANS OF FORMER STUDENTS DUE TO BANKRUPTCY, DEATH AND/OR DISABILITY.

MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE MAJORITY OF GRANTS GIVEN TO STUDENTS IN THE UNITED STATES PRIMARILY CONSIST OF NEED-BASED GRANTS. STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THESE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BY COMPLETING TWO FORMS THAT ESTABLISH ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. THESE ARE STANDARD FORMS USED IN HIGHER EDUCATION FOR THIS PURPOSE: COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE AND FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR AMOUNTS GIVEN TO STUDENTS AS FINANCIAL AID ARE APPLIED BY THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. HAMPSHIRE COLLEGE GRANT AID ASSISTANCE IS GENERALLY LIMITED TO THE AMOUNT OF TUITION. THE COLLEGE ALSO OFFERS FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. THESE ARE SIMILARLY APPLIED BY THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE AND DO NOT EXCEED THE AMOUNT OF TUITION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY OF DAYTON IS AN INDEPENDENT UNIVERSITY THAT PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE STUDENTS QUALIFY TO RECEIVE THIS AID BASED UPON THEIR FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC TALENT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED THAT DOCUMENT THE STUDENTS' FINANCIAL NEED, ELIGIBILITY TO QUALIFY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AND THE AMOUNTS AWARDED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.

ALL GRANTS REPORTED IN PART III OF SCHEDULE I ARE TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WITH THEIR COSTS OF ATTENDANCE. GRANTS ARE ELECTRONICALLY TRANSMITTED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID INTO THE ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE SYSTEM OF THE BUSINESS OFFICE BASED UPON SYSTEM IDENTIFICATION NUMBERS FOR INDIVIDUALS. EACH STUDENT IS ABLE TO COMPARE THE AID POSTED AGAINST HIS BILLING STATEMENT FOR TUITION AND FEES TO THE AWARD LETTER HE RECEIVED FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. ADDITIONALLY, DURING THE COLLEGE'S ANNUAL AUDIT, THIS PROCESS IS TESTED FOR ACCURACY NOT ONLY OF AMOUNTS AND ASSIGNMENT TO CORRECT INDIVIDUALS, BUT ALSO FOR ANY RESTRICTIONS OF GRANT FUNDING REGARDING AWARDEE ATTRIBUTES REQUIRED TO QUALIFY FOR ANY PARTICULAR AWARD. LINE THREE IN PART III REPORTS THE FEDERALLY FUNDED SUPPLEMENTAL GRANTS; THE COLLEGE ANNUALLY CONTRACTS FOR AN AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE UNIFORM GUIDANCE.

THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THROUGH CONTROLS WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING AND INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT OFFICES. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR RECEIVES, VETS, AND COORDINATES SUBMITTALS FOR GRANTS. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR MONITORS THE AWARDS OF FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR AND ACCOUNTING OFFICE MONITOR WORK PERFORMED, BILLING, GRANT CLOSE OUT, AND POST GRANT REPORTING. THE VP OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS AND THE VP OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION OVERSEE AND/OR APPROVE GRANTS.

CIIS OFFERS INSTITUIONAL FUNDED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED BY EACH STUDENTS EFC (EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION) WHICH IS CALCULATED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION BASED ON THE STUDENTS FASFA. ALL STUDENTS MUST BE FULL-TIME AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING TO RECEIVE THE OPPORTUNITY SCHOLARSHIP. OPPORTUNITY SCHOLARSHIP IS CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AND IS AUTOMATICALLY APPLIED TO TUITION AND FEES ONLY.

The University's Enrollment Services Division, Office of Student Financial Services, and Office of Research Services and Sponsored Projects responsible for the administration of all grants and student aid according to current law, regulations, and policies prescribed by grantors. The University is subject to annual audits conducted in accordance with OMB Circular A-133.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS STUDENT ELIGIBILITY BASED ON THE CRITERIA SET BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION ON FEDERAL STUDENT AID PROGRAMS. STUDENTS ARE NOT AWARDED FEDERAL STUDENT AID IF THE CRITERIA FOR RECEIVING SUCH AID IS NOT MET. ANY CONFLICTS THAT ARISE MUST BE RESOLVED PRIOR TO THE AWARDING OF FUNDS. SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED BY THE COLLEGE ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE CRITERION SET BY THE DONOR. EACH WEEK THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE NOTIFIES THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF ANY STUDENT(S) WHO HAVE WITHDRAWN FROM CLASSES. A REVIEW IS DONE TO DETERMINE IF THE STUDENT IS STILL ELIGIBLE FOR BOTH FEDERAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS. DESIGNATED STAFF MUST REVIEW THE STUDENTS FILE AND CONTACT THE STUDENT TO DISCUSS OPTIONS FOR REGAINING STUDENT AID ELIGIBILITY. UNTIL THE ISSUE IS RESOLVED THE STUDENT IS NO LONGER ELIGIBLE FOR FEDERAL AID OR COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS (IF APPLICABLE). THE AID WILL BE REMOVED UNTIL ELIGIBILITY HAS BEEN REESTABLISHED.

THE ESTIMATE INCLUDED IN PART III, COL (B) REPRESENTS THE UNDUPLICATED STUDENT COUNT AS OBTAINED FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FOR ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED A SCHOLARSHIP DURING THE FISCAL YEAR SEMESTERS. IF THE STUDENT RECEIVED IN ALL SEMESTERS, THEY ARE ONLY COUNTED HERE ONE TIME.

All scholarships are awarded to students who have completed the college's admissions requirements and have registered for classes. Scholarships require a student to maintain a full-time status throughout the semester and are awarded for one year; divided evenly between the Fall and Spring semesters. Most scholarships are renewed annually as long as the student meets the renewal criteria, completes the FAFSA. Music and athletic scholarships require re-evaluation each year and are not automatically renewed. Scholarships are awarded with the understanding that a student will complete the semester for which the award is received. A student must be in good standing and making satisfactory progress in order to receive a scholarship.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED BY OUR STUDENT ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES DEPARTMENT FOR PROPER USE & AWARDING. ALL GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS ARE FOLLOWED & DOCUMENTED IN THE SAS OFFICE RECORDS.

ALL GRANTS AND AWARDS MADE BY CENTRAL CHRISTIAN COLLEGE IN KANSAS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE UNDER THE GUIDELINES AND REGULATIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. ALL SUCH GRANTS, AWARDS, AND SCHOLARSHIPS APPEAR ON THE INDIVIDUAL AWARD LETTERS THAT ARE SIGNED BY THE STUDENT RECIPIENTS. THESE SAME GRANTS AND AWARDS CAN BE TRACED DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND ON THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S ACCOUNTING SYSTEM.

ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN U.S. DUKE UNIVERSITY PERIODICALLY APPROVES GRANTS AND TRANSFERS GRANT FUNDS TO NUMEROUS ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. FOR SUBGRANT RECIPIENTS, A SERIES OF INTERNAL CONTROLS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED WHICH INCLUDE DETERMINATION OF WHETHER AN AUDIT WILL BE REQUIRED. DUKE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED A DETAILED AND COMPETITIVE APPLICATION PROCESS WHICH ENSURES PROPER PURPOSE AND USE OF THESE GRANT FUNDS PRIOR TO ENGAGEMENT. FOLLOWING THE PROCUREMENT PROCESS, DUKE UNIVERSITY MONITORS SUBSEQUENT BILLING AND PERFORMANCE OF THE GRANT RECIPIENTS. INVOICES MUST BE SUBMITTED ACCORDING TO THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS WHICH MIRROR THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE ULTIMATE GRANTOR. PRIOR TO PAYMENT, CENTRALIZED DEPARTMENTS REVIEW DOCUMENTATION TO ENSURE THE EXPENSES ARE ALLOWABLE WITHIN THE TERMS OF THE GRANT. ULTIMATELY, THE ORGANIZATIONS AWARDED THESE GRANTS MUST MONITOR THE APPROPRIATE DISTRIBUTION OF THESE GRANT FUNDS IN THE ORDINARY COURSE OF BUSINESS AND REPORT SUCH INFORMATION TO DUKE UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS' INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID IS POSTED DIRECTLY TO THEIR BURSAR ACCOUNTS. THEREFORE, SUCH FUNDS ARE DIRECTLY APPLIED TO APPROPRIATE CHARGES WITHIN THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS. GRANT/FELLOWSHIP PAYMENTS ARE PROCESSED ACCORDING TO AWARD LETTERS, WHICH ARE REVIEWED AND SUBMITTED TO THE RECIPIENT IN ADVANCE OF ACCEPTING FOR THE APPLICABLE SEMESTER. EACH PAYMENT IS PREPARED ACCORDING TO THE AWARD LETTER BY A DEPARTMENTAL REPRESENTATIVE, WHICH IS THEN REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY A DEPARTMENTAL SUPERVISOR. PRIOR TO ISSUANCE, A FINAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL IS PROCESSED BY THE CENTRAL PAYMENT PROCESSING DEPARTMENT.

The College provides grants to certain charitable organizations within the Worcester area. These grants are closely tied to promoting the Colleges charitable and educational mission and contribute to the enrichment of the greater Worcester area.

The College supports a need based financial aid policy that is representative of its academic and spiritual goals as an undergraduate, Jesuit, liberal arts college. The College accepts students regardless of their ability to pay needs-blind admission and meets their full demonstrated need, as calculated according to nationally recognized financial aid criteria. All students are encouraged to apply regardless of their socio-economic background. Over 50 of all students admitted receive some form of financial assistance. Students are require to maintain satisfactory adademic progress to receive aid.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS GRANTS BASED ON NEED TO NEW AND CONTINUING STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED A FAFSA AND ARE CONSIDERED TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID. THE DOCERE AND TOLEE TOTUM GRANT AWARDS ARE FUNDED BY INSTITUTIONAL FUNDRAISING EFFORTS. BOTH AWARDS EMBODY THE SPIRIT OF NATUROPATHIC MEDICINE, WHERE DOCERE IS A "DOCTOR AS TEACHER- AND TOLEE TOTUM IS "TREAT THE WHOLE PERSON". THE ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT EXECUTIVE SERVES AS THE SCHOLARSHIP REVIEW COMMITTEE IN REVIEWING AND DETERMINING THE AWARDS. THE DOCERE AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT AND NEED. THE TOLEE TOTUM AWARDS ARE ALSO BASED ON NEED AND AN ESSAY WHERE APPLICANTS IDENTIFY WHAT THE PRACTICE OF NATUROPATHIC MEDICINE MEANS TO THEM AND HOW A GRANT AWARDS WOULD AID THEM IN REACHING THEIR EDUCATIONAL GOALS. WHEN ESTABLISHING THESE GRANT AWARDS, THE ORGANIZATION SEEKS TO REWARD STUDENTS WHO HAVE ACHIEVED HIGH ACADEMIC SUCCESS AS WELL AS THOSE WHO WILL BENEFIT THE MOST FROM THE GRANT AWARD. AS STATED IN THE ORGANIZATION'S COURSE CATALOG, THE ORGANIZATION DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, DISABILITY, SEX, RELIGION, AGE, NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, OR MARITAL STATUS IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF EDUCATIONAL AND ADMISSION POLICIES, FINANCIAL AID, EMPLOYMENT OR ANY OTHER PROGRAM OR ACTIVITY. THIS STATEMENT APPLIES TO THE AWARDING OF SCNM SCHOLARSHIPS.
ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND PAY FOR TUITION AND FEES. PER OTIS POLICY, BFA/MFA SCHOLARSHIPS DO NOT EXCEED TUITION AND FEES.

COLLEGE FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AS WELL AS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM RESTRICTED SOURCES (NEED AND MERIT BASED) PROVIDED TO STUDENTS OF THE FOUR SCHOOLS OF THE COLLEGE. THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENTS ACCOUNTS AND ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE CONTROLLER'S OFFICE.

WYOMING SEMINARY AWARDS FINANCIAL AID ON A COMPETITIVE BASIS TO STUDENTS WHOSE FAMILIES DEMONSTRATE THE NEED FOR SUCH FUNDING. TO OBJECTIVELY ASSESS NEED, FAMILIES MUST COMPLETE AN ONLINE APPLICATION WITH AN INDEPENDENT 3RD PARTY, SCHOOL AND STUDENT SERVICES (SSS), AND SUBMIT THEIR MOST RECENT TAX DOCUMENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS INDIVIDUALLY TO DETERMINE AWARDS FOR STUDENTS BECAUSE THE DEMAND FOR FINANCIAL AID OUTWEIGHS AVAILABLE FUNDS EACH YEAR.

ENDOWED AND ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON CERTAIN CRITERIA SET BY THE INSTITUTION (DUNWOODY) AND DONORS. STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS STARTING SPRING QUARTER OF THE PREVIOUS SCHOOL YEAR. APPLICATIONS ARE COMPILED AND REVIEWED BY A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE CHOOSES THE STUDENT OR STUDENTS WHO ARE MOST DESERVING OF THE AWARD BASED ON THE CRITERIA AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS ARE NOTIFIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF THE ACCEPTANCE TO THE AWARDS WHICH THEN BECOME PART OF THEIR FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AS A CREDIT ON A QUARTERLY BASIS WHICH REDUCES THEIR TUITION. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO WRITE A THANK YOU NOTE TO THE DONORS OF THE SCHOLARSHIP SHOWING THEIR APPRECIATION. IF A THANK YOU NOTE ISN'T WRITTEN, THE STUDENT DOESN'T RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM SCHOOL, THE SCHOLARSHIP IS REVOKED.

Procedures and conditions are designed to ensure that individuals receiving disbursements are adequately investigated to ensure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy based on the institution's assessment of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.
Funding for students' mission trip

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: AWARDS TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED THROUGH OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

All scholarships are awarded upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED AWARDS. THE NEED-BASED AWARDS ARE BASED ON THE FAFSA FORM THAT IS SUBMITTED BY UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND AWARDED ACCORDING TO THEIR FINANCIAL NEED. MERIT-BASED AWARDS ARE BASED ON SAT, GPA, AND OTHER TEST SCORES. UNIVERSITY AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS TO STUDENTS ACCORDING TO UNIVERSITY POLICIES. FUNDS ARE MANAGED BY THE OFFICES OF STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS TO COMPLY WITH ALL APPLICABLE COMPLIANCE REGULATIONS.
CASH GRANTS ARE CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Monitoring the expenditures of grant funds is done in accordance with Stone Child College's financial policies and procedures manual, Section III - Financial. Also, as a condition for receipt of grant funds, the college must allocate these funds according to the requirements of each specific federal grant and ensure compliance with federal regulations for uses of these funds. The business office provides fiscal oversight for all financial affairs to ensure that these funds are being used in compliance with all policies and procedures. The approval process for all expenditures require three signatures: the person requesting the use of funds, the project coordinator/director, then the president has the final approval. A monthly expenditure report for all programs administered by the college and a monthly check register is provided to the College's governing board for their review and approval at their monthly meetings.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS CHARGED WITH DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY, ALLLOCATIONS OF GRANT FUNDS, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED AFTER AN ANALYSIS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) IS COMPLETED. THE COLLEGE ALSO OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, WITHOUT REGARD TO NEED, TO ENTERING NEW AND TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC RECORDS. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS CHARGED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.
The University awards financial aid to students based on certain eligibility requirements. The University's financial aid package is on file at the University and is available upon request.

THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES FOR DETERMINING ELIGBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, PRIZES AND OTHER GRANTS AND AWARDS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS SHOWING RECIPIENT ELIGIBILITY,HOW FUNDS MAY BE USED, AND ANY RELATED PARTY DISCLOSURES. GRANTS AWARDED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNTS. OTHER GRANTS ARE MONITORED IN VARIOUS WAYS, INCLUDING REIMBURSING ACTUAL SUBSTANTIATED EXPENSES, REQUIRING WRITTEN REPORTS AND /OR VISITING SITES OF ACTIVITIES FUNDED BY COLLEGE GRANTS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND MONITORS GRANTING OF AWARDS TO STUDENTS AND FOLLOWS U.S. FEDERAL AID REGULATIONS AND ALL STATES' REGULATIONS FOR GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS.

The organization uses congressional methodology from the U.S. Department of Education need analysis. It assigns student eligibility based on effective family contribution from the Pell Processing Center. All records on packaging as well as awarding are processed through the organization's PowerFAIDS system.

THE COLLEGE'S DEPARTMENT OF FINANCIAL AID REVIEWS AND APPROVES THE PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE FUNDS. THE CONTROLLER AND DIRECTOR OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS AND APPLY GENERAL ACCOUNTING PROCEDURES IN BOOKING THE FUNDS ON FINANCIAL RECORDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 IN RECOGNITION OF THE CLOSE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE COLLEGE AND THE CITY OF BEVERLY, AN ANNUAL GIFT IS PRESENTED TO THE MAYOR OF THE CITY TO ASSIST IN THE FURTHERANCE OF THE CITY OF BEVERLY'S INITIATIVES. THE COLLEGE PROVIDED BEVERLY MAIN STREETS WITH GENERAL SUPPORT TO PROMOTE AND ENHANCE DOWNTOWN BEVERLY'S ECONOMIC VITALITY, CULTURAL AND HISTORIC RESOURCES AND QUALITY OF LIFE. ENDICOTT COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS THROUGH ITS OWN RESOURCES, AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE PROGRAMS. TO QUALIFY FOR SCHOLARSHIP OR GRANT AID, A STUDENT MUST BE ENROLLED IN AN APPROVED PROGRAM AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING. MOST OF THE AID PROGRAMS REQUIRE THAT A STUDENTS DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED. ENDICOTT AWARDS ARE MADE ON A FUNDS-AVAILABLE BASIS TO DESERVING STUDENTS. THE COLLEGE MAKES EVERY EFFORT TO ENSURE THAT A QUALITY EDUCATION IS AVAILABLE TO ALL STUDENTS, REGARDLESS OF INCOME LEVEL, RACE, RELIGION, DISABILITY, NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN, AGE, OR GENDER.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, HOUSING STATUS, AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE UNIVERSITY. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: RECORDS MAINTAINED FOR GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The University has agreements with various government agencies regarding annual contributions. Also, Each year the University makes numerous small contributions to community organizations. THE UNIVERSITY'S Department of Community and Regional Affairs reviews requests from local non-profits, and looks to provide program support for organizations in the Princeton area who provide important services and resources to the community. All Contributions are evaluated to assure that they support the Princeton community at large. The University's Pace Center for Civic Engagement provides grants and support efforts by students, faculty, staff, and alumni to identify and address issues of public concern, to be actively engaged citizens, and to practice effective public leadership for the purpose of building stronger communities and societies throughout the world. THE UNDERGRADUATE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MAINTAINS THE RECORDS RELATED TO THE UNDERGRADUATE NEED-BASED GRANTS. THE PROCEDURE IS AS FOLLOWS: THE STUDENTS APPLY ANNUALLY FOR GRANTS BASED ON THEIR FAMILIES' FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. EACH APPLICATION IS THEN REVIEWED TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF GRANT THAT IS NEEDED. THE GRANTS ARE PROVIDED FROM APPROPRIATE SOURCES AND APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S PRINCETON BILL FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM, BOARD AND OTHER CHARGES. At the time of admission, graduate student fellowships are awarded on the basis of a combination of academic merit and financial need. All students must remain in good academic standing in order to receive funding. Students in certain programs receive research grants after their first year of study, While other students receive fellowships for the duration of their program. Graduate student fellowships are funded through a combination of university resources including endowment, general university funds, and/or departmental resources.

Schedule I, Part II In furtherance of its research activities, Princeton University makes sub-awards to other institutions that perform research in connection with research grants awarded to Princeton University. Princeton University does not categorize these sub-awards as "grants and other assistance" for Form 990 reporting, since the recipient organizations perform research services for the University and are considered independent contractors which serve the direct needs of the University. During the year ended June 30, 2016, Princeton University made sub-award payments to 219 recipient organizations totaling $24,577,605.

GRANTS ARE MADE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND STIPENDS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS. TOCC MAINTAINS RECORDS OF STUDENTS' QUALIFYING CRITERIA AND SEEKS TO ENSURE THAT EVERYONE HAS ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION REGARDLESS OF NEED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, WORK-STUDY AND STUDENT LOANS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL AID VARIES BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF EACH AWARD. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, SAT OR ACT SCORE AND CLASS RANK, AND/OR EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND WHO, BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NEED-BASED AID. ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE SELECTED FOR VERIFICATION BY THE CENTRAL PROCESSING SYSTEM (CPS) MUST ALSO SUBMIT VERIFICATION OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FAFSA. NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE FEDERAL PELL GRANT AND FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG), STATE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, AND EMMANUEL COLLEGE GRANT AID. IN ADDITION TO NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS WHO APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID AND DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED MAY ALSO RECEIVE FEDERAL WORK STUDY AND NEED-BASED FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT LOANS. THE LOAN PROGRAMS OFFERED BY EMMANUEL COLLEGE ARE THE FEDERAL STAFFORD LOAN, THE FEDERAL PERKINS LOAN AND THE MASSACHUSETTS NO-INTEREST LOAN. PRIOR TO DISBURSING ANY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, WORK-PROGRAM OR STUDENT LOAN IS CERTIFIED. TO RECEIVE NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID EACH ACADEMIC YEAR.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

AS OUTLINED IN SCHEDULE I, PART III, LA SALLE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS RECORDs TO QUANTIFY THE DOLLAR AMOUNT OF THE STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AWARDED, THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS PER GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: A UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF THE LOWCOUNTRY EDUCATION IS AN INVESTMENT IN YOUR CHILDS FUTURE. IT IS ALSO A SIGNIFICANT FINANCIAL INVESTMENT. OUR FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM PROVIDES NEED-BASED TUITION ASSISTANCE TO FAMILIES WHO WOULD OTHERWISE NOT BE ABLE TO ATTEND USL. NO STUDENT WHO MEETS THE ADMISSIONS CRITERIA SHOULD BE DETERRED BY FINANCIAL REASONS FROM APPLYING TO UNIVERSITY SCHOOL. PARENTS WHO REQUIRE AID ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY FOR AN AWARD. GRANTS OF FINANCIAL AID ARE NOT INTENDED TO COVER 100% OF THE COST OF ATTENDANCE AT USL: THE CURRENT POLICY FOR MAXIMUM AWARD IS 90%. ALL FAMILIES ARE EXPECTED TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE COST OF THEIR STUDENTS EDUCATION. FAMILIES ARE ASKED TO SUBMIT FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ONLINE, AND FINANCIAL AID DECISIONS ARE MADE INDEPENDENTLY OF ADMISSIONS DECISIONS. APPLICATIONS ARE PROCESSED BY FAST FINANCIAL AID FOR SCHOOL TUITION, AND THE RESULTS ARE RETURNED TO UNIVERSITY SCHOOL. THERE IS A 38 APPLICATION PROCESSING FEE THAT MUST BE PAID VIA CREDIT CARD AT THE TIME THE ON-LINE APPLICATION IS SUBMITTED.THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM IS MANAGED IN ACCORDANCE WITH USL'S NON-DISCRIMINATION POLICY. WHEN SUBMITTING TAX FORMS TO FAST, PLEASE WRITE "UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF THE LOWCOUNTRY" UNDER YOUR RETURN ADDRESS ON THE ENVELOPE TO SPEED THE PROCESSING OF YOUR APPLICATION.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH THE NECESSARY STAFF, POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THE UNIVERSITY ADHERES TO AND COMPLIES WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ADEQUATE STAFFING IN ITS OTHER GRANT PROGRAMS WITH ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE, THE UNIVERSITY ALSO UNDERGOES THE REQUIRED OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AUDITS.

The Business office reviews the recipient's Form 990 and A-133 audit report if available. The Director of the program at VLS works closely with the recipient of the funds that will be paid by the grant to coordinate activities/training essential for program effectiveness. The recipient submits invoices to VLS which are reviewed and approved by the Program Director to substantiate the grant related purpose. The invoice is then forwarded to the business office for review and coding to the proper accounts. The funds are then forwarded to the recipient. If deemed necessary, VLS may carry out an on site monitoring visit for general training, reviewing of the recipient's procedures/records and informing the recipient of grant requirements.

CARTHAGE COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

The University utilizes several procedures and reports on an annual basis to monitor financial aid. The University has internal controls in place to ensure amounts are awarded to students who continue to meet and maintain eligibility requirements. These controls are administered through the Financial Aid office. Also, Independent Auditors complete the A-133 Audit relating to federal and state student aid.

SEVERAL PROCEDURES AND REPORTS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR FINANCIAL AID INCLUDING: THE UNIVERSITY HAS IN PLACE INTERNAL CONTROLS TO ENSURE AMOUNTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO CONTINUE TO MEET AND MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. THESE INTERNAL CONTROLS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, INDEPENDENT AUDITORS COMPLETE THE A-133 AUDIT RELATING TO FEDERAL STUDENT AID, THE FISAP REPORT FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, COMMON DATA SET (CDS) WHICH IS A SET OF STANDARDS AND DEFINITIONS AMONG THE HIGHER EDUCATION COMMUNITY & PUBLISHERS AS REPRESENTED BY THE COLLEGE BOARD, PETERSON'S, US NEWS & WORLD REPORT & THE WINTERGREEN ORCHARD HOUSE.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE COLLEGE'S ONLY GRANT-MAKING ACTIVITY IS TO PROVIDE SCHOLARSHIPS TO THOSE STUDENTS THAT MEET CERTAIN FINANCIAL AND MERIT CRITERIA. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DEDUCTED FROM EACH RECIPIENT'S BILL FOR TUITION AND FEES. AS SUCH, THE COLLEGE IS ASSURED THAT ITS GRANTS ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSE OF HELPING STUDENTS WITH EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO ADMITTED STUDENTS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF THEIR ACADEMIC PROFILE AND A CAREFUL ANALYSIS OF THEIR DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS AWARDED GRANT FUNDS MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND REMAIN ENROLLED AT THE UNIVERSITY ON A FULL TIME ACADEMIC BASIS. AT THE END OF EVERY TERM, EACH STUDENT'S ACADEMIC STATUS (I.E., GPA) IS MONITORED TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY FOR ALL GRANT FUNDS RECEIVED. FOR MONITORING PURPOSES, ELECTRONIC REPORTS GENERATED FROM OUR DATABASE ARE UTILIZED FOR THE AWARD DETERMINATION AND STATUS REVIEW PROCESS. THE UNIVERSITY ENSURES THAT ITS GRANT FUNDS ARE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES BY CREDITING THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER FINANCIAL AID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS RATHER THAN ISSUING CHECKS.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID, DEVELOPMENT, AND BUSINESS OFFICES TOGETHER ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. THREE DIFFERENT OFFICES ARE INVOLVED IN THE PROCESS FOR ADEQUATE CHECKS AND BALANCES. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE VERIFIES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS AND AWARDS THE GRANT FUNDS. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE CLOSELY MONITORS THE RESTRICTIONS PLACED ON THE GRANT FUNDS FROM THIRD PARTIES. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE ENSURES THAT THE GRANTEES SELECTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FULFILL THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER THE RESTRICTIONS ON THESE GRANTS. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE USES INTERNAL REPORTS PROVIDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ASSIST WITH THIS PROCESS. THESE INTERNAL REPORTS PROVIDE BASIC DATA ON STUDENT ELIGIBILITY, SUCH AS MAJOR, GPA, AND EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE REPORTS BACK TO THE APPROPRIATE GRANTORS CONCERNING THE USE OF THE GRANT FUNDS. THE BUSINESS OFFICE POSTS THE DISBURSEMENT OF GRANT FUNDS TO THE GENERAL LEDGER UPON RECEIVING CONFIRMATION FROM THE FINANCIAL AID AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICES. ALL GRANT INFORMATION IS KEPT ON A SECURE DATABASE. THIS DATABASE INCLUDES THE NAMES OF THE STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS, THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS, THE CRITERIA USED TO AWARD GRANTS, AND THE APPLICABLE SEMESTER AND ACADEMIC YEAR.

The University utilizes several procedures and reports on an annual basis to monitor financial aid. The University has internal controls in place to ensure amounts are awarded to students who continue to meet and maintain eligibility requirements. These controls are administered through the Financial Aid office. Also, Independent Auditors complete the A-133 Audit relating to federal and state student aid.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Administration, monitoring and oversight of grants is conducted to oversee the progress and completion of the grants , ensuring compliance with all relevant terms and conditions.

Financial aid awards are granted to students based on the general criteria for institutional financial aid. Financial aid is applied directly to student accounts through the college's academic management system.
FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDS APPROPRIATELY. FUNDS ARE TRANSFERRED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS TO COVER FEES. NO OVER-AWARDING IS PERMITTED.

SAINT LOUIS UNIVERSITY OFFERS A NUMBER OF INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS. EACH PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC AWARDING CRITERIA AND INDIVIDUAL RULES FOR AWARDING SET UP IN THE BANNER (ERP) SYSTEM. INITIALLY, AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES OR THE DEPARTMENT ADMINISTRATORS WILL DETERMINE AND NOTIFY THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES. AWARDS ARE THEN POSTED ACCORDINGLY AND DISBURSED ONTO A STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. STUDENTS REGISTERED IN THE BANNER (ERP) SYSTEM WILL BE AWARDED AND PAID USING THE STUDENT INFORMATION SYSTEM DISBURSEMENT RULES. CONTROLS ARE IN PLACE TO MONITOR OR DESIGNATE IF CHARGES AND RESULTING PAYMENT OF AID IS APPLICABLE TO THE TYPE OF PROGRAM OR FEE BY USE OF SEPARATE DETAIL CODES FOR EACH PROGRAM.

Basis of verified financial need or merit and does not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of race, color, national or ethnic origin, religion, age, sex disability or prior military service. Financial assistance is monitored so that it is in compliance with awarding terms and conditions. Expenditures are reviewed for allowability and compliance. Students are required to submit appropriate documents prior to approval. Part III: Cash grants are credits to student accounts and the number of recipients represents only the numbers of students receiving institutional funding. Outside grants, or applications of funds provided by outside agencies (e.g. federal loan programs) is not included.

Keck Graduate Institute of Applied Life Sciences awards scholarships only to individual students enrolled at the Institute. The scholarships are awarded in the admissions process based upon academic merit, financial need, and availability of funds. The Institute monitors that each student receiving a scholarship maintains satisfactory academic progress. In awarding donor-funded scholarships, the Institute also monitors that students selected for those scholarships meet any donor stipulations as to academic preparation or field of study.

Valparaiso University is committed to providing resources necessary to help students complete their education. In selecting the students to receive this assistance, the University places primary emphasis on the student's academic achievement and financial need. Awards are determined by the University Scholarship Committee. Upon enrollment verification, the awards are used to offset the cost of attendance.

Grants distributed by Dartmouth consist primarily of scholarships, fellowships and related support given to Dartmouth students. Scholarships are awarded based on the financial need of the student. Scholarship applications are reviewed by a financial aid officer. Financial aid officers are expected to recuse themselves from any case in which they either have a personal interest or feel they cannot be impartial. A random sampling of cases read by each undergraduate financial aid officer is reviewed by the Associate and Senior Associate Directors to ensure compliance with federal regulations, adherence to Dartmouth policies, consistency in results and accuracy. Scholarships are credited to an individual student's account through the Banner Student Information system after the student has enrolled for the term (these credits are included in "non-cash assistance" in Part III above) Scholarship funds are withdrawn if the student ceases to be enrolled. Fellowships are granted in support of a student's educational or research endeavors. All educational and research work is monitored by Dartmouth faculty. Dartmouth Ventures is an annual conference and contest on entrepeneurship sponsored by Tuck School of Business. The contest is open to any startup team or company having at least one member with a Dartmouth College affiliation. Entries are evaluated by a group of Dartmouth College alumni, entrepeneurs and expert business practitioners, on the basis of which business is most likely to create significant social and/or economic value.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE COLLEGE AWARDS AID TO MEET 100% OF A STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED NEED. ALL AID IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. IF THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM WELLESLEY, THE AID IS ADJUSTED ACCORDINGLY. FOR INTERNSHIPS, THE COLLEGE IS IN CONTACT WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS PROVIDING THE INTERNSHIP TO ENSURE THAT HIGH-QUALITY PROGRAMS ARE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENTS.

Schedule I Part I line 2 The University monitors their respective grants by establishing a separate accounting for each individual grant. All transactions are reviewed and approved by appropriate personnel prior to submission for processing to ensure they meet the requirements of the grant.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGE, AND OTHERS AS ESTABLISHED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP DOCUMENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS TO PAY TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD EXPENSES.THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS SHOWN FOR SCHEDULE I PART III IS BASED ON THE NUMBER OF GRANTS AWARDED. THIS AMOUNT IS USED AS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS AWARDED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS.

THE UNIVERSITY OF DENVER HAS A UNIVERSITY WIDE SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT ALLOCATION SYSTEM THAT DISTRIBUTES GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO ALL DIVISIONS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PURPOSE AND ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA ARE ESTABLISHED AT THE FUND LEVEL. THE EXPENDITURE OF THIS FINANCIAL RESOURCE IS MONITORED THROUGH A COMPREHENSIVE SOFTWARE SYSTEM WHICH ALLOWS FOR RECONCILIATION, ELIGIBILITY CHECKS, AND PREVENTS OVER EXPENDITURE. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PARTICIPATES IN ANNUAL INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AUDITS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN RECIPIENTS ARE DIRECTLY APPLIED TO THE RECIPIENTS' TUITION AND FEE RECEIVABLE ACCOUNT AND IS APPLIED TO ANY OUTSTANDING CHARGES PRIOR TO DISBURSEMENT OF ANY EXCESS AMOUNTS.

DISBURSEMENTS TO STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS & FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THOSE RECEIVING AID ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID AND/OR ASSISTANCE FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES IS DISTRIBUTED & MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERALLY APPROVED NEED ANALYSIS CRITERIA OR OTHER AGENCY PROVIDED CRITERIA. THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE MONITORED THROUGH UNIQUE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT. EXPENDITURES FOR EACH GRANT ARE REVIEWED AND ANALYZED USING AD-HOC REPORTS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE. GRANTS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS ARE ADJUDICATED BY A PANEL OF NATIONAL EXPERTS USING THE FOLLOWING CRITERIA TO EVALUATE GRANT APPLICATIONS: EXCELLENCE, ABILITY TO IMPLEMENT PROJECT, AND PROJECT IMPACT. THESE CRITERIA INSURE THAT THE FUNDING ALIGNS WITH THE GRANT-MAKING GOAL OF SUPPORTING THE PHILADELPHIA REGION'S MOST TALENTED ARTISTS AND HIGH-PERFORMING CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS. THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO ORGANIZATIONS ARE MONITORED THROUGH UNIQUE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT. EXPENDITURES FOR EACH GRANT ACCOUNT ARE REVIEWED AND ANALYZED USING AD-HOC REPORTS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE.

Explanation: The Federal and State funds provided for financial aid to students of Rose-Hulman follows all regulations. Each year the regulations are evaluated to verify that all regulations are being followed based on each funds criteria.

The College monitors the use of grant funds by verifying student enrollment records maintained by the Office of the Registrar and the Office of Student Accounts. Enrollment verification is performed prior to awarding of grant funds and throughout the academic year. The Office of Financial Aid monitors the College's compliance with grant agreement requirements throughout the academic year, and keeps current with compliance requirements by participating in professional development workshops and reviewing federal compliance updates from the Department of Education and NASFAA.
GRANTS ARE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO STUDENTS AND ARE GIVEN AS A REDUCTION OF OUTSTANDING TUITION.
SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TOWARDS OUTSTANDING TUITION.

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY, REVIEWING BALANCES, AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WTIH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT THE EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORY AND BUDGETARY AMOUNT. THIS INCLUDES REVIEWING EXPENSE CATEGORIES, REBUDGETING OR TRANSFERRING EXPENSES AS NEEDED, AND DETERMINING IF THE AWARD WILL BE UNDERSPENT AT THE END OF THE BUDGET OR GRANT PERIOD.

THE COLLEGE GRANTS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE COLLEGE'S DEGREE-GRANTING PROGRAM. THE COLLEGE DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE STUDENT'S NEED. SOME SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE COLLEGE HAS A STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OFFICE THAT ACCUMULATES ALL REQUIRED INFORMATION FROM THE STUDENTS. THE OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED UPON CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE THROUGH ITS FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE AMOUNTS, ELIGIBILITY, AND SELECTION CRITERIA USED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE ASSISTANCE BY REVIEWING GRADE TRANSCRIPTS AND ATTENDANCE RECORDS ON A QUARTERLY BASIS.
Scholarships are issued based on financial need and good academic standiNg. Scholarships are applied against students' tuition account. No cash is distributed to students.

THE COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION POLICY REGARDING TITLE IV FUNDS. THE COLLEGE HAS DEDICATED INDIVIDUALS PERFORM THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE SCOPE OF THE GRANT WHO WORK TO ENSURE PROPER STEWARDSHIP OF FUNDS. THESE INDIVIDUALS FOLLOW THE STATUTORY AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN THE GRANT. FUNDS ARE DRAWN AFTER EXPENSES ARE INCURRED. PROGRESS REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED.

Goucher College's institutional grant funds are limited to need-based and merit-based financial assistance for attendance at the College. Goucher College's comprehensive program of need-based and merit-based financial assistance is managed by the Office of Student Financial Aid. As a member of the College Board and in keeping with the principles and practices of the College Scholarship Service, need-based financial aid is awarded to properly qualified candidates on the basis of financial need of students and their families. Financial need is determined by subtracting the Expected Family Contribution -as calculated on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and the Profile Form of the College Scholarship Service - from the student's total cost of attendance. Financial aid is awarded for one year only and must be renewed annually. Need-based aid is renewed to continuing students who demonstrate need and who are making satisfactory progress toward their degrees. Institutional merit-based scholarship requirements vary depending on the award. Compliance with those requirements is also overseen by the Office of Student Financial Aid.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The college reports are regularly reviewed to be certain funds are used for proper purposes. Federal grant reporting and reconciliation occurs monthly and during the yearly single audit. Awarding practices are reviewedforcompliance with federal regulations. Students are reviewed yearly for continued and new fund eligibility to be sure academic standards and other grant-specific criteria have been met.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE, ALL FUNDS ISSUED TO STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO STUDENT MAY USE THE FUNDS FOR OTHER THAN EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SINCE THE STUDENTS HAVE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS ONCE ISSUED.

GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS REQUIRE QUARTERLY PROGRAM REPORTING INCLUDING A NARRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SUMMARY THAT IS REVIEWED BY THE PROGRAM DIRECTOR. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE COLLEGE. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE COLLEGE'S POLICY.
NSF SUBAWARD - STEP CENTER/INTEGRATE: INTERDISCIPLINARY TEACHING OF GEOSCIENCE FOR A SUSTAINABLE FUTURE

Part I Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANTS LISTED ON SCHEDULE I REPRESENT SCHOLARSHIP PROVIDED TO STUDENTS WHO MATRICULATE AT THE UNIVERSITY. AS SUCH, NO MONITORING OF THE GRANT FUNDS ARE REQUIRED BECAUSE THE STUDENT MAY ONLY USE THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
THE COLLEGE HAS POLICIES AND PROCEDURES IN PLACE THAT ARE FOLLOWED IN ORDER TO AWARD STUDENTS INSTITUTIONAL AID.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS ARE PLACED DIRECTLY INTO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT WITH THE COLLEGE. THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS ARE USED TO PAY THE COST OF TUITION AND FEES OF THE COLLEGE.

Harding University awards financial assistance to its students on basis of the verified financial need or merit and does not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of race, color, national or ethnic origin, religion, age, sex, disability or prior military service. Financial assistance is monitored so that it is in compliance with awarding terms and conditions. Expenditures are reviewed for allowability and compliance. Students are required to submit appropriate documents prior to approval.
Cash grants are credits to students accounts.

IN AS MUCH AS ALL GRANTS ARE FOR NON-CASH ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENT recipients' TUITION, ROOM, BOARD OR BOOKS, WHEN SUCH REMISSION OCCURS, IT IS A DIRECT REDUCTION OF THE STUDENTS FEES TO THE UNIVERSITY. SINCE NO GRANT FUNDS ARE IN DIRECT CONTROL OF THE RECIPIENT, THE RECIPIENT IS NOT IN A POSITION TO DIVERT THE GRANT FROM ITS INTENDED USE. FOR ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS, THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR AND DIRECTOR OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH NAIA RULES, MUST MONITOR SCHOLARSHIP EXPENDITURES FOR EACH STUDENT AND PROGRAM.

THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO ENSURE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON FEDERAL REGULATIONS OR DONOR RESTRICTIONS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH IN THE INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS. "NEED BASED" FEDERAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL AID (FASFA).
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 SU PROVIDED APPROXIMATELY $301 MILLION IN INSTITUTIONAL AID TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2016. THE AID PROVIDED CONSISTS OF A COMBINATION OF NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED GRANTS. STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THESE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BY COMPLETING TWO FORMS THAT ESTABLISH ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID: THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE, AND THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. THESE ARE STANDARD FORMS USED IN HIGHER EDUCATION FOR THIS PURPOSE. BOTH NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS IS APPLIED BY THE UNIVERSITY DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY LIMITED TO THE AMOUNT OF TUITION. STUDENTS REACHING THE "TUITIONARE INELIGIBLE FOR ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS FROM THE UNIVERSITY. NEED-BASED AID CAN BE USED FOR ALL EDUCATIONAL RELATED EXPENSES IN ADDITION TO TUITION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART II THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES AND RECEIVED ACKNOWLEDGEMENT THAT MONIES REPRESENT CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR EACH ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSE.

PART III, COLUMN B THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS WHO RECEIVED SCHOLARSHIPS WAS DERIVED BY QUERYING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT DATABASE IN THE STUDENT RECEIVABLE SYSTEM FOR ACADEMIC TERMS WITHIN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2016. THE QUERY LOOKED FOR TUITION DISCOUNT (FINANCIAL AID) AND OTHER ASSISTANCE USING THE DEFINITION OF SUCH ITEMS AS REPORTED IN THE UNIVERSITY'S AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. THIS PRODUCED A REPORT OF ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED AID. RECOGNIZING THAT A STUDENT COULD BE RECEIVING AID IN MORE THAN ONE ACADEMIC TERM, THE INFORMATION WAS THEN SORTED BY INDIVIDUAL AND THE STUDENT WAS COUNTED ONLY ONCE PER FINANCIAL AID TYPE.

MONITORING GRANT FUNDS: GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE USED FOR TUITION AND ALLOWABLE EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES. AWARDS ARE BASED ON NEED DETERMINED FROM A FEDERAL FAFSA APPLICATION. GRANT FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE TUITION AND FEES OF THE AWARDEE AND DO NOT LEAVE POSSESSION OF THE COLLEGE, THEREFORE NO MONITORING IS NECESSARY.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ALL SWARTHMORE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED/POSTED ELECTRONICALLY (AND INTERNALLY) DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. FURTHERMORE, STUDENTS RECEIVING SAID FUNDS ARE UNABLE TO WITHDRAWAL IT FROM THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT.
GSSIMR PROVIDED FELLOWSHIP STIPENDS AND NON-CASH ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF HOUSING, BOOKS, AND COMPUTERS TO RESEARCHERS DURING THEIR PERIOD OF STUDY AND RESEARCH.

MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNT TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO INSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT OR SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. NOTIFICATIONS ARE SENT BY THE DEAN OF THE COLLEGE TO ALERT DEPARTMENTS OF WITHDRAWALS. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HRS FOR EACH STUDENT. THIRD PARTY SOFTWARE IS ALSO CODED TO PREVENT THE CREDIT OF FUNDS TO A STUDENT WITHOUT ENROLLED HOURS.

The University assigns responsibility for monitoring the use of grant funds within the United States to the Office Of Post Award Financial Operations. This office monitors all grant making activity, including COMPLIANCE WITH all applicablE regulations. Expenses are accounted for on an accrual basis. Schedule I, Part III Boston University makes every effort to assist students with calculated financial eligibility and high academic achievement, measured against the credentials of other accepted students. A student's academic record is an important factor in determining eligibility for Boston University scholarships and need-based grants. Key indicators such as high school grade point average (GPA), rank in class, and standardized test scores are considered, as well as the strength of the student's academic program and extracurricular activities.
GRANTS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE GIVEN TO STUDENTS ATTENDING THE COLLEGE. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE FUNDS THAT ARE GIVEN TO EACH STUDENT.

The College awards scholarships and financial aid awards. These funds are disbursed by the College's Financial Aid Department in strict adherence to all Federal and state regulations. The College also grants money to Earlham Foundation, a related organization, to hold and invest the assets on the College's behalf.

HERITAGE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN FEDERAL GRANTS AND LOAN PROGRAMS. ALL OF THE STUDENT AWARDING PROCESS IS DOCUMENTED IN THE SOFTWARE USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND TRACK STUDENT AWARDS. FOR THOSE AWARDS WITH SUBJECTIVE SELECTION CRITERIA, THE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR SUCH AWARDS OR GRANTS. HERITAGE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES A YEARLY AUDIT OF THE GRANTS AND OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH A-133; A-87; AND OTHERS.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANTS THE TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MAINTAINS A POLICY OF OFFERING QUALIFIED UNDERGRADUATE APPLICANTS ADMISSION TO THE UNIVERSITY WITHOUT REGARD TO FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCE. THIS POLICY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF DIRECT GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS AN ALL-GRANT POLICY WHEREBY ANY QUALIFIED UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED RECEIVES A LOAN-FREE AID PACKAGE. STUDENTS MAY STILL BORROW AT THEIR DISCRETION TO SUPPLEMENT THEIR AID PACKAGES. AN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF TUITION REMISSION AS A RESULT OF A PARENT BEING ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THIS BENEFIT AS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT. GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL AID CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, SERVICE (TEACHING ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS) OR OTHER CRITERIA SUCH AS MERIT/ACADEMICS. PHD STUDENTS GENERALLY RECEIVE MULTI-YEAR AWARDS COVERING THEIR FULL EDUCATIONAL COSTS. A GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF BENEFIT AS DESCRIBED ABOVE. --------------------

DETAIL OF SUB-CONTRACTS IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, THE TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MAKES SUB-CONTRACTS TO OTHER INSTITUTIONS THAT PERFORM RESEARCH IN CONNECTION WITH RESEARCH GRANTS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT CATEGORIZE THESE SUB-CONTRACTS AS GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE FOR FORM 990 REPORTING. DURING THE YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2016, THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MADE SUB-CONTRACT PAYMENTS TO 320 RECIPIENTS TOTALING $96,639,737.

Disbursements in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the institutions governing board designed to insure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the institution in furtherance of its exempt purpose are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution on the basis of criteria such as academic achievement (fellowships) and financial need (scholarships and fellowships).

FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ADMISSION TO POMONA COLLEGE IS ON A NEED BLIND BASIS. THIS POLICY IS MAINTAINED TO ACCOMPLISH DIVERSIFICATION OF THE STUDENT BODY REGARDLESS OF THE FINANCIAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANTS. A PERMANENT FILE OF ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF POMONA COLLEGE. AN ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TRACKS ALL AWARDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS FOR TUITION AND OTHER COSTS OF ATTENDING THE COLLEGE.

The College provides individual scholarship assistance to enrolled students in order to defray the cost of tuition and fees. This assistance is provided through direct credit to the student's account with the college, ensuring funds are utilized for their intended purpose. Depending on the source of funds, there may be donor stipulations which students may need to adhere to in order to maintain eligibility of funds. In the event of such, ongoing monitoring is performed by the College's Financial Aid department.

THE COLLEGE HAS ESTABLISHED POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND CONTROLS OVER THE AWARDING, DISBURSING, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OR ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE OF NEW YORK REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, ATHLETIC MERIT AND ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE. STUDENT LOANS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FEDERAL ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION DIRECT LENDING PROGRAM. STUDENT ATHLETICS MUST FOLLOW THE RULES SET FORTH BY THE NCAA. ONCE A SCHOLARSHIP HAS BEEN AWARDED, THE UNIVERSITY CHECKS THE RECIPIENTS' GRADE POINT AVERAGE AT THE END OF EACH SCHOOL YEAR TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE MEETING THE ACADEMIC STANDARD SET FORTH BY THE SCHOOL OR DONOR. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AT JOHNSON C. SMITH UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CHECKING EACH ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENT'S GRADES BEFORE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE NEXT SCHOOL YEAR. STUDENTS NOT MEETING SAP (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS) WILL LOSE THEIR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, THE PARENTS OF THE RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A COPY OF THE TAX RETURN EACH YEAR TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE BEFORE NEW NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED. STUDENTS RECEIVING ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS MUST MAINTAIN A 2.0 OR HIGHER GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND MUST PASS AT LEAST 6 CREDIT HOURS IN THE FALL SEMESTER AND 24 CREDIT HOURS FOR THE SCHOOL YEAR. THE ATHLETICS COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR CHECKS THE GRADE REPORT FOR EACH STUDENT ATHLETE. EACH STUDENT ATHLETE'S GRADE REPORT IS EXAMINED AT THE END OF THE SEMESTER TO SEE IF HE OR SHE IS MEETING THE SET STANDARDS. IF THEY ARE NOT MEETING STANDARDS, THEY WILL LOSE THEIR SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, IF A STUDENT WITHDREW FROM THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE COMPLETING 60 PERCENT OR MORE OF A SEMESTER, THEIR FINANCIAL AID INCLUDING INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PRORATED BASED THE R2T4 (RETURN OF TITLE 4 FUNDS) CALCULATION.

COSTS CHARGED TO SPONSORED AGREEMENTS ARE FULLY INTEGRATED WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING SYSTEM. THE SYSTEM ACCUMULATES COSTS ACCORDING TO INDEX, FUND AND ACCOUNT CODE CATEGORIES. ASSOCIATED AND IDENTIFIED WITH EACH FUND ARE VARIOUS ATTRIBUTES SUCH AS PROJECT TITLE, SPONSOR, AND PRINCIPAL.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.

AWARDING OF INSTITUTIONAL AID IS DRIVEN BY THE AWARD THE STUDENT RECEIVES UPON ENTRANCE TO KEUKA COLLEGE. COMING IN AS A NEW STUDENT, THE ADMISSIONS AND FINANCIAL AID SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE FIRST DETERMINES IF THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS. THESE AWARDS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC AND CO-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. EACH STUDENT IS THEN REVIEWED FOR NEED-BASED GRANT FUNDING, CAMPUS BASED AID AND CAMPUS EMPLOYMENT TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY. STUDENTS ARE PLACED ON THIS GRID BY USING THE ADMISSION'S SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA TO DETERMINE THEIR RATING AND THEN THEIR FINANCIAL NEED FACTOR AS DETERMINED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FOR THAT ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENT AWARDS ARE REVIEWED ON A YEARLY BASIS TO DETERMINE THEIR ELIGIBILITY. TYPICALLY A STUDENT AWARD WILL NOT CHANGE UNLESS FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC PROGRESS CHANGES. TUITION BASED AWARDS WILL INCREASE/DECREASE WITH THE VALUE OF TUITION EACH YEAR. INSTITUTIONAL AID IS PLACED ON THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT TYPICALLY IN TWO EQUAL DISBURSEMENTS (FALL AND SPRING). THESE DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT RELEASED UNTIL ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION IS COMPLETE IN THE STUDENT'S FILE. DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE 10 DAYS PRIOR TO THE START OF CLASSES EACH SEMESTER. INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATE, INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS AND A LIMITED NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN THE GRADUATE AND ACCELERATED STUDY PROGRAM.

The College follows federal guidelines for determining the financial need of each student attending programs outside of the United States. The College Board Profile and the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) provide us with information to determine financial need. Grants and scholarships are awarded based on the demonstrated need of each student.

As federally mandated, the School prepares annually a student cost of attendance budget, which includes tuition, room and board, and an estimate for the cost of books, supplies, transportation, and personal expenses. The School then awards federal, state and institutional aid based upon the cost of attendance and the family's expected contribution, as determined by the Federal needs analysis formula. Students do not receive funding in excess of the cost of attendance, and in cases where outside grants are received, student self-help aid (i.e. loans and work-study) is reduced first to ensure that aid is not over-awarded. Students must document additional educationally-related expenses in order to receive funding above their unmet needs.

THE THREE AREAS OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS ARE LOANS, GRANTS, AND EMPLOYMENT (WORK-STUDY). THESE ARE GENERALLY AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ANOTHER SOURCE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, ATHLETICS OR PERFORMING ARTS, COMMUNITY SERVICE OR LEADERSHIP. CRITERIA FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS MAY ALSO INCLUDE A FINANCIAL NEEDS REQUIREMENT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE AMOUNT ISSUED BY CALCULATING A COST OF ATTENDANCE, ASSESSING AN ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC), AND DERIVING A LEVEL OF FINANCIAL NEED. ONCE THE AMOUNT OF AID HAS BEEN DETERMINED FOR THE INDIVIDUAL, IT IS DISPERSED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND IS CONTROLLED BY THE BURSAR'S OFFICE. SEVERAL REPORTS/SURVEYS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANT ASSISTANCE; FOR EXAMPLE, FISAP REPORT TO USDE, A-133 AUDIT, FEDERAL IPEDS REPORT, STATE ANNUAL AUDIT, AND VARIOUS SURVEYS THAT TYPICALLY USE INFORMATION FROM THE COMMON DATA SET (CDS).
THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE PRACTICE OF DIRECTLY APPLYING SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT AT THE UNIVERSITY TO OFFSET TUITION AND FEES.

During fiscal year 2016, Hillsdale College awarded monetary grants/prizes to five institutions based on specified criteria. One prize recognizes one outstanding public or private school teacher with his/her school receiving the funds. The recipient is chosen among the teachers nationally who are implementing the ideas and curriculum contained in a comprehensive educational resource designed by Hillsdale College professors. The school is required to prepare an annual report on the expenditure(s) of the Prize until such funds are entirely expended. Three other grants supported the launch of K-12 charter schools which are based on a classical liberal arts model and which have a strong civics component which will equip students to understand and defend the principles of the American founding. The recipients are required to provide Hillsdale College documentation on the use of the funds in addition to on-site visits by Hillsdale College staff. The last grant was to provide a fellowship in education.

ORGANIZATION PROVIDES NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS APPLYING FOR SCHOLARSHIPS MUST PROVIDE EVIDENCE OF NEED. EACH APPLICATION IS REVIEWED BY A COMMITTEE TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.ORGANIZATION PROVIDES FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED OF INDIVDUAL.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: ORGANIZATION IS PROVIDED WITH DOUMENTATION OF USE OF FUNDS FOR THEIR GRANTS AND IS IN CONSTANT CONTACT WITH MANAGEMENT OF HELPING HANDS TO ENSURE THEIR FUNDS ARE PROPERLY SPENT.

Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S. The University made need-based and merit-based grants and scholarships to 1507 students in fiscal 2015, totaling $30,021,107. Additionally, the University awards various federal, state, and private scholarship, loan, and student work programs as part of its overall financial aid program. The University Financial Aid office is responsible for management of all financial aid programs. The University uses the Department of Education methodology to determine family need for awarding need-based awards. Merit-based awards are determined based on various academic (GPA, rank in class, etc.) as well as other qualitative measures. It is the responsibility of the Financial Aid office to ensure compliance with federal and state regulations on financial aid, and the University policy and internal control objectives. The financial aid office and its operations are subject to internal control review by the University's external auditors as part of the annual financial statement audit. Additional monitoring is also provided through the review and oversight of Senior Management, Senior Staff, the Dean of Enrollment Services, and the Business Office, all of which are under the purview of the Audit Committee and the Board of Trustees' Fiscal Affairs Committee. Additionally, the University's awarding and management of financial aid awards is subject to an annual Single Audit (Circular A-133) and State of Texas audits (for various state financial aid programs). Results of these audits are reported to the University Senior Staff, the Board of Trustees' Audit Committee, and the Board of Trustees Fiscal Affairs Committee.

Monterey College of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. The scholarships are awarded by a scholarship committee populated by members of the board of trustees. The scholarships are awarded each Fall and Spring semesters. Most scholarships are need-based or based on academic achievements. Monterey College of Law maintains complete records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

EXPENDITURE REQUESTS ARE INITIATED AT THE DEPARTMENT LEVEL (I E THE PI, OR THEIR DESIGNEE REQUESTS THAT THEIR DEPARTMENT MAKE A PURCHASE ON THEIR BEHALF). EXPENDITURE REQUESTS ARE SUBMITTED IN WRITING EITHER BY USING A PURCHASE ORDER, CHECK REQUEST, TRAVEL VOUCHER, OR, ON RARE OCCASIONS, A MEMO TO PRECLUDE INCURRING OBLIGATIONS IN EXCESS OF TOTAL FUNDS AVAILABLE FOR THE AWARD. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS ALL EXPENDITURE REQUESTS, PRIOR TO BEING INCURRED, TO ENSURE THAT THERE IS ADEQUATE BUDGET AVAILABLE FOR THE PURCHASE. THE GRANT ACCOUNTANT IS IS REQUIRED TO REVIEW GRANT BUDGETS PERIODICALLY. THE GRANT ACCOUNTANT REVIEWS THE EXPENDITURE REQUESTS TO ENSURE THAT NO BUDGET CATEGORIES ARE OVERRUN AND REVIEWS THE EXPENSE LIST FOR ANY UNUSUAL ACTIVITY. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS AWARD-ELATED EXPENDITURE REQUESTS FOR COMPLIANCE WITH OMB COST PRINCIPLES. RECONCILIATIONS ARE PREPARED BY THE GRANT ACCOUNTANT FOR MAJOR GRANTS AND ARE REVIEWED BY THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR FISCAL AFFAIRS AND CONTROLLER.

The College follows federal, state, and institutional policies and regulations to monitor grants and funds: (1) the student applies for the grants; (2) grants are awarded from the various funding sources depending on need and/or academic standing; (3) the students eligibility is verified through federal, state, and institutional requirements, matriculation, registration, attendance, and academic progress; (4) grants and awards are processed onto the student's account; (5) where loans are involved, the College follows up with the regulatory requirements after graduation. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is an integral part of this process.

THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT WHICH FOLLOWS THE FEDERAL LAWS REGARDING STUDENT FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING AID AND COLLEGE GRANTS. STUDENT GRANTS ARE POSTED TO STUDENT BILLING ACCOUNTS AS A PART OF THEIR FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT PROVIDE GRANTS TO ANY OTHER ORGANIZATIONS OR INDIVIDUALS.
ALL GRANT AID IS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS AT SHIMER COLLEGE. EACH STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO FILE A FAFSA IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERAL GUIDELINES.
GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND ACCOUNTING OFFICES.
The Financial Aid office monitors the awards of all federal student aid grants
SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE BASED ON APPLICATION PROCESS, EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTIONS AND COST OF TUITION.

THE SCHOLARSHIPS GRANTED BY ADRIAN COLLEGE ARE USED TO PAY TUITION AND FEE CHARGES ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE SCHOOL IS ALSO ABLE TO MONITOR WHETHER STUDENTS REMAIN AT THE COLLEGE THROUGH THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE, THE VICE PRESIDENT AND DEAN OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS' OFFICE, CLASS ATTENDANCE TAKEN BY FACULTY, AND HOUSING RECORDS MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT AFFAIRS'OFFICE
THE ORGANIZATION MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES BY ONLY DONATING TO THE RELATED ORGANIZATIONS LISTED UNDER SCHEDULE R.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS:
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE HAS DESIGNED AND IMPLEMENTED INTERNAL CONTROLS THAT INCLUDE FINANCIAL REPORTING AS WELL AS INTERNAL CONTROL OVER COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS AND GRANT AGREEMENTS. INCLUDED IN THE INTERNAL CONTROL STRUCTURE IS A COMPREHENSIVE GRANTS AND CONTRACTS POLICY THAT PROVIDES THE ECKERD COLLEGE COMMUNITY GUIDELINES FOR GRANTS RECORDKEEPING, REPORTING AND MANAGEMENT. THE FINANCIAL AID AND BUSINESS OFFICES HAVE PRIMARY ROLES IN THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS WHICH INCLUDES PROCEDURES FOR FINANCIAL REPORTING, FUNDS REQUESTS, INVOICING, REIMBURSEMENTS, PROGRAM ACTIVITY OVERSIGHT, PURCHASES, CLOSE OUT AND POST AWARD COMPLIANCE. THE BUSINESS OFFICE COMMUNICATES DIRECTLY AND FREQUENTLY WITH FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL COLLEGE POLICIES. THE COLLEGE IS ALSO SUBJECT TO EXTERNAL AUDITS WHICH ARE PERFORMED AT LEAST ANNUALLY.

ALL FIRST-TIME STUDENTS TO MITCHELL COLLEGE ARE REVIEWED FOR MERIT AID. THERE IS NO SEPARATE APPLICATION PROCESS. IF STUDENTS ARE AWARDED MERIT AID, THE NOTIFICATION LETTER WILL BE SENT ABOUT TWO WEEKS AFTER THEIR ACCEPTANCE LETTER ARRIVES. MERIT AID IS BASED ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND/OR COMMUNITY SERVICE INVOLVEMENT. STUDENTS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN OBTAINING NEED BASED AID, EITHER FROM FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCES OR MITCHELL COLLEGE'S OWN FUNDS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AT WWW.FAFSA.ED.GOV. FINANCIAL AID, SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED IS APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH A REDUCTION IN TUITION CHARGES.

FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ADMISSION TO POMONA COLLEGE IS ON A NEED BLIND BASIS. THIS POLICY IS MAINTAINED TO ACCOMPLISH DIVERSIFICATION OF THE STUDENT BODY REGARDLESS OF THE FINANCIAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANTS. A PERMANENT FILE OF ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF POMONA COLLEGE. AN ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TRACKS ALL AWARDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS FOR TUITION AND OTHER COSTS OF ATTENDING THE COLLEGE.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON MERIT OR FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS APPLY FOR INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS THROUGH THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT AND ARE AWARDED BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIP - THEY ARE AWARDED BY A COMMITTEE. ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED DURING THE RECRUITMENT PROCESS AND ARE AWARDED BASED UPON MERIT.
